Braulio is a young person who has experience in this line of work, as he has been doing this type of work for some time now.

Braulio needs the loan that he is requesting from Edpyme Alternativa for 1,000 Peruvian soles so that he can buy iron window grills and a door for his home.  In this way he can contribute to his household by making his parents' house more secure.  In addition, this is where he parks his mototaxi for the night, the main tool of his work.

Braulio is a new client of Edpyme Alternativa, but he has good personal and work references.

loans.use: to buy steel security bars for the windows and doors of his house

loans.name: Maria Del Rosario

texts.es: Maria Del Rosario se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras. Es una persona muy humilde se siente muy contenta de tener un trabajo todos los días, ella deposita su confianza diariamente en su negocio. Hace más de 31 años que inicio con este medio de vida, las ganas de salir adelante es lo que ha hecho que Maria tenga su negocio. El motivo del crédito es para la compra de melones, sandias, bananos, naranjas, aguacate. Desea  que su negocio salga adelante pues siempre brinda el mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
María Del Rosario sells fruit and vegetables.  She is a very humble person who feels happy to have work every day.  She places her trust in her business daily.  

She started this way of life over 31 years ago.  The desire to get ahead in life prompted María to have this business.  

The reason for the loan is to purchase melons, watermelons, plantain, oranges and avocadoes.  She hopes her business will continue making progress because she always provides the best possible service to her customers.

loans.use: to buy melons, watermelons, plantain, oranges and avocadoes.

loans.name: Kankeletigui 1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe KANKELETIGUI 1 est une Association  de femmes mariées du village de Dembela dans la préfecture de NIENA région de SIKASSO troisième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Le groupe est compose de 10 femmes qui vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux-parents, belles-sœurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans et 5 enfants. Elles exercent la culture d’arachide de riz et de mil.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour des frais de labours, acheter  une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, de riz des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, exclusivement  au grand marché de Dembela et de Nina ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues au grand marché de NIENA et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
YATA compte acheter, 1 sac d’urée, 2 sacs de complexe céréale et le reste comme frais de labour et de sarclage.  Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 30.000 à 40 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Kankeletigui 1 group is an association of married women from the Dembela village in the Niena prefecture, Sikasso region (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The group is made up of ten women who live in large, traditional extended families with their children, husbands, inlaws, etc. They have an average age of 34 and 5 children each. They farm peanuts, rice, and millet.

In order to make their agricultural operations profitable, the group members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program. This loan will be utilized to pay plowing costs and to buy rice and peanuts for planting, small farming equipment, and additional planting supplies, all at the big market of Dembela and the city of Niena.

After the rainy season, the harvests will be stocked in order to increase their value before being sold at the big market in Niena as well as surrounding markets, both retail and frequently wholesale, on a cash basis to clients generally from large cities.

Yata plans to buy 1 bag of carbamide and 2 bags of cereal fertilizer, and use the rest to pay for plowing and hoeing. He plans to make an average profit of 30,000 to 40,000 FCFA, which will be used to pay interest on the loan and for daily family expenses.

loans.use: to buy planting supplies and pay plowing costs.

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio is 60 years old and lives in Puntod, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental, Philippines.  He is married and has 2 adult children.  To earn a living,  Antonio operates a specialized retail store which sells assorted products.  He has owned this business for 20 years and earns PHP 20,000 per month.  But Antonio not content with this amount of income per month. He wants to add more stocks to his grocery store to increase his sales. So, he has requested a loan of PHP 50,000 from GDMPC to buy additional stocks to sell to multiply his income each month.

Antonio has been a member of GDMPC for 3 years. In the future, he wants to expand his current retail store and open a larger grocery store in the city.

loans.use: buy additional stocks to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 47 years old, married, and has five children age 1 to 10. 

He operates a small kiosk where he sells items like mandazi (a pastry), tilly (cooking fat), bread, sugar and rice. James has been in business for five years. He intends to use his loan to purchase more rice that he intends to sell. 

James hopes to expand his business into wholesale. He also hopes to buy a plot of land to build rental houses. James describes himself as visionary.

loans.use: to purchase more rice that he intends to sell.

loans.name: Jose Damian

texts.es:
José, es agricultor, se dedica a sembrar maíz y frijol, también a la crianza de ganado, él vive acompañado de su esposa y un hijo de 2 años de edad, José tiene 10 años de trabajar con ganado y agricultura, aprendió de su padre y hasta la fecha está contento con su oficio.
Actualmente solicita un préstamo para la compra de insumos agrícolas, ya que está sembrando maíz y frijol y necesita abono y fertilizantes para reforzar la plantación, de esta manera se estará asegurando del crecimiento del maíz y la planta de los frijoles, aunque su producción depende casi siempre de las condiciones del clima.
Él espera que todo su proceso del cultivo sea correcto, tener una producción abundante que le permita comercializar una parte y también su familia se alimente de este trabajo.
texts.en:
José is a farmer.  He grows corn and beans and also raises livestock.  He lives in the company of his wife and two-year-old son.  José has worked with livestock and in farming for ten years having learned from his father; to date he’s happy with his occupation.

He is currently asking for a loan to buy farming supplies because he’s planting corn and beans and needs manure and fertilizer to strengthen his plants in order to insure the growth of the corn and the bean plants although his crop yields depend for the most part on the weather conditions.

He hopes that the entire growing process will be correct and to have an abundant harvest that will allow him both to sell part of it and also that his family can feed itself thanks to this work.

loans.use: to buy manure and fertillzer for his corn and bean crops.

loans.name: Meriecris

texts.en:
Meriecris is 32 years old and married. She has two children aged 3 and 7. Her husband works as a farmer and a technician.

Meriecris is a farmer who works in the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She grows rice and vegetables to sell. Meriecris requested a loan to purchase seedlings, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes to own a bigger farm in the future.

loans.use: to purchase seedlings, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Librando

texts.es:
Librando de 48 años de edad, vive con su esposa e hijos en su casa propia, cuenta con servicio sólo de luz, ubicada en la zona rural del departamento de Piura.  Esta zona se caracteriza por la actividad agrícola, ganadera y turismo.

Desde hace 3 años Librando se dedica a la preparación y venta de soya (es un granos que se remoja de un día para otro, luego se licua y por último se hierve con otros ingredientes quedando como un refresco), esta bebida es muy consumida por los pobladores en reemplazo de la leche, es muy agradable, su producto lo vende cerca al mercado de la zona donde vive, también cuenta con su propia clientela que le hace pedidos diarios y con esos ingresos pretende solventar sus obligaciones familiares.

Ha solicitado préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 600 nuevos soles para comprar mayor cantidad de soya para seguir comercializando y de animales de corral para criar y vender, con las ganacias que obtenga podrá pagar su crédito y ayudar a su familia.  Librando es una persona que con esfuerzo y trabajo saca adelante diariamente a su familia, lo que le da mucha alegría.
texts.en:
Librando is 48, and lives with his wife and children in their own house. The house only has electricity, and is located in the rural area of the Piura department. This area is characterized by farming, livestock-raising and tourism.

For three years Librando has been working on the preparation and sale of soy. The beans are soaked overnight, then liquified. Lastly, they are boiled with other ingredients, ending up as beverage. This drink is much consumed by the local people as a replacement for milk; it is very pleasant-tasting. He sells his product near the market of the area where he lives. He also has a his own clientele that order from him every day, and with this income he tries to meet his family obligations.  

He has applied to Edpyme Alternativa for a loan of 600 nuevos soles to buy more soy to keep selling, and to buy livestock to raise and sell.  With the earnings he gets he will be able to pay back the loan and help his family. Librando is a person who with hard work helps his family get ahead every day. This gives him much joy.

loans.use: To buy more soy beans and livestock to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy old warm clothes

loans.name: Benkadi  4 Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe BENKADI  4 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, 3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à MAARO, un village situé à environ 45 km de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième cycle prêt avec l’institution. Les prêts ante rieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est : le riz et l’arachide  avec Madame MAMOU              debout à l’extrème gauche avec la foulard rouge.
Avec son prêt, elle compte payer les frais de labours, acheter des intrants et des semences pour entretenir : 2 hectares. 
La production est vendue au niveau du village de LOUTANA et au marché de SIKASSO après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 160 000 FCFA  en fin de  campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The six members of the group called BENKADI 4 are married women with an average age of 32 and on average, three children, who  mostly live in polygamous families in MAARO, a village situated about 45 km from the town of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali. They work with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso so as to succeed in their agricultural activities during the rainy season. They are on their fifth loan with the institution. Their prior loans have been correctly reimbursed.

The crops cultivated are rice and peanuts, in the case of Madame MAMOU, standing on the far left with a red scarf. With her loan she intends to pay for plowing and buy inputs and seed to maintain 2 hectares. The produce is sold right in the village of LOUTANA and at the market of SIKASSO after the harvest, to a clientele composed of men and women. She expects to make a profit of 160,000 F CFA at the end of the growing season. This profit will allow her to repay her loan and also to help her husband with daily expenses.

loans.use: to buy inputs, pay for plowing, and purchase seed.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en: Evangeline is 43 years old and married with 3 children.  For the past 10 years she has been earning a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. She earns additional income from running a sari-sari store and farming rice. She is borrowing PHP 27,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.  She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Sembrando Group

texts.es:
La señora Magdenia nació en la ciudad D. Espinar y radica hace 24 años en la ciudad D. Cusco. (La socia está levantando la mano en la fotografía). 

La señora Magdenia tiene 24 años y tiene una relación D. libre unión, ella es una mujer trabajadora, responsable y  profesional, ella es docente y trabaja en un colegio D. la ciudad D. Cusco. Ya es un año que enseña y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. En esta oportunidad Magdenia requiere el préstamo para comprar materiales como por ejemplo cuadernos, pizarras, lapiceros y otras cosas mas.

Las reuniones D. las socias D. Banco Comunal “Sembrando” son cada treinta días en la ciudad D. Cusco. El banco Comunal está conformado por personas que son trabajadores y emprendedores que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos. La mayoría D. los socios viven en la ciudad D. Cusco y sus actividades económicas D. los demás socios son por ejemplo venta D. cosméticos, venta D. comida, venta comestibles, venta D. ropa, venta D. verduras y otros brindan servicios varios. 

Cusco es conocido por ser una zona muy turística, comercial, por su fiesta tradicional D. Inti Raymi y porque se encuentra una D. las siete maravillas D. mundo “Machupicchu”. (Los socios que está en la parte inferior D. la fotografía llegaron tarD. a la reunión D. banco comunal).
texts.en:
Magdenia was born in the city of Espinar and has lived in Cusco for the last 24 years. (She is raising her hand in the photo.)

Magdenia, 24, is in a common law relationship.  She’s a hardworking, responsible, professional woman.  She’s a teacher working in a school in the city of Cusco.  She’s been teaching for a year and does well thanks to the dedication she puts into her work.  On this occasion, Madgenia needs the loan to buy supplies like notebooks, blackboards, mechanical pencils and other things.

The meetings of the “Sembrando” (Planting) communal bank take place very thirty days in the city of Cusco.  The communal bank is composed of hardworking, enterprising people who are always looking for opportunities to get ahead and through their daily efforts proviD. better futures for their children.  Most of the members live in the city of Cusco.  The economic activities of the rest of the members are, for example, cosmetics sales, food sales, grocery sales, clothing sales, vegetable sales and other proviD. various services.

Cusco is known for being a very touristy, commercial zone as well as for its traditional “Inti Raymi” festival and because one of the Seven Wonders of the World, Machupicchu, is located here.  

(The members appearing in the bottom of the photo arrived late at the communal bank meeting).

loans.use: to buy supplies like notebooks, blackboards, pencils, etc.

loans.name: Merla

texts.en:
Merla is 39 years old, married with 2 children. One child is in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Merla has a sari-sari store business in the Philippines. Merla requested a PHP 12,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more goods to sell in her sari-sari store.

Merla has been in this business for 2 years. In the future, Merla would like to save enough so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more goods to sell in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Kupha

texts.en:
Kupha is married and her husband works as a farmer. She has 6 children – 4 adults and 2 who are currently enrolled in school. Kupha has run a small kiosk for the past 5 years, and her primary customers are neighbors and passersby. Violet's other source of income includes earnings from her adult children. She describes her greatest business challenge to be low turnover and her highest monthly expense is food. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

Kupha will use the Kes 80,000 loan to buy more inventory, such as soap, cooking oil and other essential goods. Kupha aspires to run her own retail shop in the future. She joined Yehu because of their convenience and flexibility.

loans.use: To buy more inventory, such as soap, cooking oil and other essential goods.

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
Bernadette resides in an urban place but lives less fortunate. She could not find good employment, so she decided to engage herself in the business of a sari-sari (variety) store selling grocery items. She has been operating this business for 10 years. 

Bernadette is now 36 years old and has two children that need daily allowances and meals. She is now asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy more grocery items, such as biscuits, eggs, vinegar, soy sauce, milk, and sugar to sell in her store.

Bernadette would like to keep growing as a successful entrepreneur and someday lift her family out of poverty.

loans.use: to buy more grocery items, such as biscuits, eggs, vinegar, soy sauce, milk, and sugar to sell in her store.

loans.name: Rahmeh

texts.en:
Rahmeh a 23-year-old divorced lady who is currently living with her parents. 

She recently started a small retail business selling blankets and she wants to expand it to include clothes too. But since her basic capital is still small she wants to work on increasing it then move to the next stage which is having a small separate retail shop. 

To be able to do that she has applied for this loan to buy more blankets and winter clothes since the winter season has started now.

loans.use: to buy more blankets and winter clothes

loans.name: Las Aguilas Group

texts.es:
La señora Maria Florinda es casada, tiene 48 años D. edad, cursó sus estudios D. primaria, tiene 1 hijo el cual esta estudiando, se dedica al bordado D. blusas, inicio este trabajo bordando como operaria y hasta el momento lleva 25 años D. experiencia, cuanta con el apoyo D. su esposo.

Organiza un grupo para solicitar un préstamo que lo utilizará para la compra D. hilos D. diferentes colores, y ampliar su producción D. blusas, espera en el futuro contar con operarias y mejor capital. Las demás integrantes se dedica al bordado, tejeduría, comercio, y a la crianza D. animales.
texts.en:
Maria Florinda is 48 years old and married.  She has an elementary school education and has one son who attends school.  Maria embroiders blouses.  She started doing this as an employee and now has 25 years’ experience.  Her husband also supports her.

She’s put together a group so that they can request a loan and use it to buy different colored threads to expand her blouse production.  She hopes that she will be able to have more employees and better capital in the future.  The other women also embroider, weave, are merchants, and raise livestock.

loans.use: to buy thread

loans.name: Rugiatu

texts.en:
This is 39 year-old Rugiatu. She is married to a businessman, and has 2 children, aged 20 and 6 years, who go to school. She has 1 additional dependent - a niece, who lives with her so she can attend a good school in town.

In 2000, Rugiatu established her retail business selling jeans, baby wrappers, blankets, blouse, nickers, and jewelry. When her mother died, Rugiatu was a child and her father could not take good care of her, so she had to live with his father's closest friend. She could not attend school because her caretaker did not think it appropriate. Several years later, the caretaker died and Rugiatu had to live with her older brother. They could barely afford to feed her, let alone pay for her schooling. So Rugiatu started trading in order to help with the household expenses. Ever since then, business is all she knows.

Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 1,798,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan of Le 4,500,000. Rugiatu has already received and successfully repaid 2 loans, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase ladies sandals - 3 cartons @ Le500,000, ladies jeans 60 pieces @ Le15,000, tights for ladies 120 pieces @ Le15,000, the balance Le300,000 as transportation. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 270,000.

In the future, Rugiatu plans to build a house with a shop and is nervous about the future because she has a lot to do, to achieve her dreams. She wants her children to be educated. The loan will help as she will generate more income to run her business. Her major challenge is the rainy season. Though she sells in a secure stall that protects from the rain, she has fewer customers and therefore less profit during this season. Competition is high but she offers affordable prices, latest designs and quality goods. She serves about 15 customers per day, all ladies in the city and nearby villages . She uses public transport to buy her goods in Guinea-Conakry twice a month. She has been reinvesting her profits into her business. Rugiatu always pays on time and will continue to do so since the access to more loans is her only source of generating income. She is hard working and honest and thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase inventory for her business

loans.name: Menime

texts.en:
Menime is 46 years of age and married with four children.

Menime owns & operates a business venture, driving a taxi.  She has three years of experience in this business.    Menime needs a loan of WST $2000 to maintain her vehicle.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve the general living conditions of her family.

In 2009, Menime joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Menime's 3rd loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to maintain her vehicle.

loans.name: Felipa

texts.es:
La señora Felipa tiene 57 años de edad, está casada con el señor Pedro quien tiene 62 años, ambos de la ciudad de Caacupé. La pareja tiene 3 hijos, todos mayores de edad e independientes.
Felipa cuenta que tiene una surtida despensa en su domicilio, desde hace ya 5 años. Ella trabaja mucho  pero también tiene necesidad de mejorar, para que de esa forma pueda ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes. Ella desea algún día tener un mini super donde tenga más variedad y de esa forma poder atraer a más clientes.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de azúcar, yerba, arroz, fideos, enlatados y demás insumos de primera necesidad, lo cual le ayudará a poder surtir su negocio y de esa forma estar preparada para la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Felipa is 57 years old. She is married to Pedro who is 62 years old. Both are from the city of Caacupé, She has three children, all of them adults and independent.

Felipa has had a diverse stockroom in her home for the last 5 years. She works a lot but still needs to improve, so that she can offer a better service to her customers. She wants someday to have a mini market where she can have a greater variety and attract more clients. 

She is asking for a loan to buy sugar, yerba (leaves from mate plant used for a popular tea-like beverage), rice, noodles, and canned goods and other supplies of basic needs, which will help her supply her business and so be ready for her client’s requests.

loans.use: to buy sugar, yerba, rice, noodles, and canned goods and other supplies

loans.name: Jennylyn

texts.en:
Jennylyn is 26 years old and married with one child currently going to school. Jennylyn works very hard to provide for her family.

Jennylyn runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell in her sari-sari store.

Jennylyn has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items such as soft drinks, candy, sardines, eggs, noodles, etc.

In the future Jennylyn would like to save enough to provide financial stability for her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional items to sell in her sari-sari (variety) store.

loans.name: Claudia

texts.es: La señora Claudia, se dedica a la costura de prendas de vestir femeninas, actualmente esta confeccionando blusas y vestidos, su domicilio se encuentra ubicado por el octavo anillo de la ciudad de Santa Cruz, esta viviendo en condición de anticrético. Es una excelente trabajadora y emprendedora, con el tiempo desea tener un taller de costura mas grande y poder emplear mano de obra y así comercializar sus productos en los diferentes mercados a nivel nacional ya que por ahora solo entrega a los distintos mercados de la ciudad de Santa cruz, con el dinero del crédito comprara tela e hilos para la confección de prendas de vestir ya que tiene un pedido que entregar. La Sra. Claudia agradeció por el apoyo brindado y por la rapidez con la que se la atendió ya que esta es la única actividad con la que mantiene a su familia.
texts.en: Claudia works making women's clothing. She is currently making blouses and dresses. Her home is located on the eighth ring road of the city of Santa Cruz, and she leases the house under an antichretic contract. She is an excellent and enterprising worker. In the future, she wants to have a larger tailoring workship and employ workers, so that she can sell her products at a range of markets on the national level. For now, she only supplies the various markets of the city of Santa Cruz. With the funds from the loan, she will buy fabric and thread to make clothing, since she has an order to fill. Claudia appreciates the support provided to her and the speed of the service, since this is the only economic activity with which she supports her family.

loans.use: to buy fabrics and thread to make clothing.

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
This is Pedro, 47, resident of Tondo, Manila, Philippines. Single, he manages his household while operating the business. At this time, he is working hard to provide income for his everyday expenses continually and help his parents financially.

Pedro operates a salon business. He offers hair styling, hair grooming and services. He also offers hair straightening. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. His salon is located adjacent to his house. He also has a variety store for additional income. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of 1,000 PHP in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy supplies for his salon such as shampoo, hair treatment creams and oils, and other things needed for his business.

Pedro dreams to be a big businessman someday and hopes to support his family and give them a good future. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his life and business every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for beauty products and hair products needed in his salon.

loans.name: Mastula

texts.en: Mastula is married with six children, and three go to school. She has no additional family members. She has a business of a retail shop and has been in this business for 4 years. She has applied for a loan of 700,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap, bags of rice, cooking oil and flour. She gets additional income from selling used clothes . She works at the market seven days a week and sells on a retail basis. Her major business challenges is price fluctuations in all the merchandise she sales. She is aspiring to own a fully stocked shop. She resides in the family home with access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap, bags of rice, cooking oil

loans.name: Felicidad

texts.en:
Felicidad was able to buy grocery items as Center for Community Transformation (CCT) was able to approve her previous loan application. She wants to thank CCT and lenders for their generosity in helping entrepreneurs financially. Without their help she’ll not be able to buy bulk quantity of grocery products to add for the business. Most of all, she wants to thank God for providing CCT and lenders as a medium of blessings to her. 

She’s determined to succeed in the business as shehas three children to support in school and other expenses that to sustain. Shespends her day managing the variety store and praying that God will send more customers and to have bigger profit. Felicidad is applying for another loan of PHP 26, 000 to buy more stocks of grocery items, bottled drinks and sacks of rice to add for the business.

Felicidad believes that if you want success to come in, you need God to be your greatest foundation. She is consistent in attending weekly fellowship group for CCT partners that consists of 15 to 30 members where she gain spiritual strength for member’s life changing testimony , share her own experience of God’s love, pay Micro Finance loans and  hear God’s word that  was conveyed to them every week.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of grocery items, bottled drinks and sacks of rice to add for her variety store.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
This business is a member of Naretoi Women Group. Group lending, also known as solidarity lending, is a mechanism that allows a number of individuals to provide collateral or guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group defaults, the other group members make up the payment amount. - Kiva Staff

She is an active lady and has experiences in various businesses such bead work. Hellen is married with four children.

Hellen joined WEEC in year 2001, received a loan of USD300. She started buying and selling Goats and sheep. The business went on well, paid up the first loan and there after, applied for a second loan. She was given a loan of USD.450 which she used to add more stock. She is unable to supply the required number to customers thus a need for more funding to increase stock.

loans.use: The amount requested for will assist her to boost her business such that she maintains and possibly add new clients.

loans.name: Sharif

texts.en:
Sharif has been engaged in the printing business for three years. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Gubadli region, and relocated to Sumgait city. This 44-year-old gentleman is a hard worker. He is married with three children. At previously has borrowed a loan of $200 from Normicro in order to purchase grocery goods. 
Now Sharif wants a second loan of $400 to rent a shop and increase his inventory of goods.

loans.use: To rent a shop and increase his inventory of goods

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: "Thanks to LAPO," says Mrs. Florence A.. She is 45 years old and married with five children. She has been a LAPO client for over 5 years. She lives in Benin City in Nigeria. Mrs. A. will use her loan of USD250 to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Phou

texts.en: Mrs. Phou S. is 37 years old and a widow with 2 children.  Her children are currently attending school.  She lives with her brother in a part of Kampong Cham Province in Cambodia. In order to supplement the family income, the diligent widow works very hard on a small farm with her brother.  They grow vegetables such as potatoes, tomatoes, carrots, lettuce and different kinds of herbs. She then sells them to the wholesaler at the market. With this business activity, she can earn around $10/day in revenue. To maximize her harvest and revenue, Phou S. is requesting a loan  of $1000 to purchase more seeds, fungicides and other cultivation tools for her farm. She hopes the loan will offer her the best opportunity to expand her business and enable her to provide a better quality of life for her family.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fungicides, and other tools for her farm

loans.name: Liliana

texts.es:
Liliana G. Nuñez has two children. The older child is nine years old; the younger child is three. She has been with Pro Mujer for four years. With the aid of a friend, she works in printing. She decorates pamphlets, posters, and other relatively inexpensive items. She was able to get the business going thanks to a loan made her many years ago. Recently, she was able to repay this loan. Initially, she could barely afford to buy leftover paper sold to her a a low cost by other printers or stationary stores. She acquired the ink by way of complimentary gifts or gifts from friends. Occasionally, Lilliana still has to stay at the press all weekend simply to make enough money to feed her children and pay the rent for her business. Currently, Lilliana needs money so that she can buy a computer for graphic design. This will help her improve her products and make her work more efficient. It will thus lead to increased revenues and a higher standard of living.

Translated from the Spanish by Susanna Heinz, Kiva Volunteer.

Liliana G. Nuñez, separada y madre de dos hijos, la mayor tiene 9 años, y el menor apenas tiene 3, es socia de Pro Mujer hace 4 años. Ella se dedica a la imprenta, trabaja con la ayuda de una amiga en la elaboración de folletos, recetarios, cancioneros y otros de bajo costo. La imprenta la pudo adquirir gracias a un crédito bancario hace muchos años, y recientemente pudo cancelar esa deuda. A un inicio, apenas podía comprar algunos restos de resmas de papel que le vendían a bajo costo otras imprentas o papeleras, y las tintas las conseguía mediante obsequios o regalos consistentes en latas o espátulas usadas. En ocasiones y por la demanda de trabajo, Liliana debe quedarse a dormir todo el fin de semana dentro de la imprenta, todo para reunir el dinero suficiente para el alimento de sus hijos y el alquiler de su imprenta. Actualmente Liliana necesita de dinero para poder comprar una computadora de diseño gráfico, con el fin de mejorar sus productos y agilizar su trabajo. Esto representará mejores ingresos y una mejor calidad de vida.

loans.use: Purchase of computer for graphic design.

loans.name: Lesly Lizeht

texts.en:
For 6 years, Lesly Lizeht C. has had a small grocery store, or pulperia as it is called in her native Honduras. She sells rice, soup, beans, soda water, and other groceries.

She is requesting this loan so she can buy more groceries to sell to more customers. She is divorced and has two children to support.

loans.use: Purchase grocery items to sell

loans.name: Malofou

texts.en: Malofou L. is a 65-year-old widowed lady with six children. She enjoys running her handicrafts business in her spare times at home because she too old to perform physically-demanding duties. She makes bags, hats, fans, and Samoan table mats and sells them at the market and in the village too. She makes them four days per week and gets a profit of 180 Tala ($72 USD) per day. Malofou  is glad that it provides financial help for her family and her personal needs.

loans.use: To buy materials and supplies for her handicrafts business

loans.name: Kahe A Group

texts.en:
Mwajuma R. lives with her mother . Mwajuma owns a fish business which she started almost 11 years ago. Working from 5am to 10 pm daily, she earns about $53 in profit a month from this business.

Mwajuma is the leader of Subgroup A of Group Kahe which totals 30 members. She will be sharing this loan with subgroup member Tabu M., who has businesses dealing in soda sales.

Mwajuma now hopes for a new loan to purchase more fish.

loans.use: to buy Fish

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en:
Kemi M. is 28 years old, married and has 2 children. She comes from Shibiri, Lagos State, Nigeria.

She designs and tailor's clothing for her clients, and have been in business for 5 years. She's requesting a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more tailoring materials for sale. She has been with Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) as a client for the past 2 years.

loans.use: To buy tailoring materials

loans.name: Rose's Furaha Group

texts.en:
Rose D. is married with three children, ages 21,13 and 5. Rose started selling clothes and beverages two years ago. Everyday, she works from 8am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

In the past, Rose has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in food vending.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Patricia Esther

texts.es:
Mrs. Patricia Esther Fernández Sánchez lives on Leoncio Prado Street in the Moche district in the Trujillo province of La Libertad, Perú. She is 25 years old, and she has completed high school. She has one child who still depends on her. Approximately two years ago, she sold lunches from her house, occasionally selling items like: polladas (chicken dinners), ceviche, patita en fiambre (a pickled pork salad), and pumpkin fitters during the afternoon. A year ago, she began her handicraft business. She makes earrings, bracelets, and necklaces with handmade materials. In addition, she knows how to make chompas (knitted sweaters), blouses and wool skits and needlepoint yarn. Her clients are her neighbors, both acquaintances and friends, who place orders with her and she makes them based on their preferences. Patricia is one of the founders of the Group Mientras Tanto "Luis Alberto Sánchez”, where she received her first loan, which she sued to buy cooking ingredients. With this loan of $200, which she will pay in four months, she will invest in costume jewels, nylon thread, and beads to make jewelry, and she will buy wool and yarn to make blouses, skirts, and tablecloths. Her biggest dream is to have a stall in the Moche market in where she can sell the products that she makes.

Translated by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Patricia Esther Fernández Sánchez vive en la calle Leoncio Prado en el distrito de Moche provincia de Trujillo en el departamento La Libertad - Perú. Tiene 25 años de edad, estudio secundaria completa. Tiene un solo hijo que aun depende de ella. Hace aproximadamente dos años vendía almuerzos en su casa, en algunas ocasiones realizaba actividades como: polladas, cebiche, patita en fiambre y picarones por la tarde. Hace un año que inició su negocio en manualidades. Elabora aretes, pulseras y collares con material artesanal, además, sabe tejer chompas, blusas y faldas de lana e hilo a punto croché. Sus clientes son sus vecinos, conocidos y amigos los cuales le hacen pedidos y ella elabora conforme su preferencia. La señora Patricia es una de las socias fundadoras del Grupo Mientras Tanto “Luis Alberto Sánchez”, lugar donde recibió su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 con el que compro los ingredientes para cocinar. Con el préstamo de S/.500.00 el cual pagara en cuatro meses, lo invertirá en la compra de piedras de fantasía, hilo nailon y perlitas para elaborar joyitas.Y para la elaboración de blusas, faldas y tapetes comprara lanas e hilos. Su mayor sueño es tener un puesto en el mercado de Moche en el que pueda vender los productos que elabora.

loans.use: To buy products for her business.

loans.name: Tania Yolanda

texts.es:
Tania Yolanda S. C. is 30 years old: she completed secondary school. She has two children in total but only one is still dependent on her. She lives in Licapa in the district of Paiján in the province of Ascope in the department of La Libertad – Perú.

Tania started her business together with her mother in a school kiosk near her house, during the school terms she makes prepared various dishes to sell such as jelly, biscuits, cake and other foods. Also during Summer she sells frozen ices outside her home. Recently, she has started-up another business which is the preparation and sale of animal feed: the idea of this business was based on the fact that various neighbours in her area are involved in rearing birds and are always buying these products.

She is a member of the Community Bank “Manos Unidas”, from whom she received her first loan of 300 Soles: with this money she bought snacks, fruits and cooking ingredients.

With this loan of 800 Soles, which she will repay within six months, she will buy: one sack of soya cake, one and a half sacks of ground maize, one sack of bran, 20 kilograms of birdfeed, fishmeal, Vitamin B complex and other raw ingredients to prepare poultry food.

Her dream is to have a mill in which she would be able to produce better-quality products.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Tania Yolanda S. C. tiene 30 años de edad, estudio secundaria completa. Tiene dos hijos en total pero solo uno aun depende de ella. Vive en Licapa en el distrito de Paiján en la provincia de Ascope en el departamento La Libertad – Perú.

La señora Tania inicia su negocio junto con su mama en el kiosco de un colegio cerca de su casa, durante la época escolar hace algunos preparados para vender como, gelatina, marcianos, flan y comida. Así también en época de verano vende raspadilla afuera de su domicilio. Recientemente ha iniciado otro negocio que es la preparación y venta de alimento balanceado, la idea de este negocio se debió a que existen por su zona varios vecinos que se dedican a la crianza de aves y siempre adquieren estos productos.

Ella es socia del Banco Comunal “Manos Unidas” lugar donde recibió su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 con este dinero compro golosinas, frutas y los ingredientes para cocinar.

Con el préstamo de S/. 800.00 el cual pagara en un periodo de seis meses comprará: un saco de torta de soya, un saco y medio de maíz molido, un saco de afrecho, 20 kilogramos de avemicina, harina de pescado, complejo B y los demás insumos para preparar el alimento de aves.

Su mayor sueño es tener un molino en el que pueda elaborar sus productos pero de mejor calidad.

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise for business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase of meat and other goods for a small cafeteria

loans.name: Sharafjon

texts.ru:
Sharafjon N., 28, is married and has two children. To provide for his family Sharafjon has to work frequently. Six years ago he opened up a small shop and sells spare parts for cars. There is work, but at the present time Sharafjon has decided to develop the business and to increase commodity circulation. Therefore he has addressed Kiva for help. He wishes to receive the loan and extinguish it within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Maria Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer.

Назаров Шарафджон -28 лет, женат и имеет двоих детей. Для того , чтобы обеспечить свою семью Шарафджону приходится много работать. Шесть лет назад он открыл небольшой магазин по продаже запасных частей для автомобилей.Работа идет , но в данный момент Шарафджон решил развивать свой бизнес и увеличить товарооборот. Поэтому он обратился к нам за помощью. Хочет получить кредит со сроком в 12 месяцев

loans.use: Increase commodity circulation

loans.name: Momodu's Group

texts.en: Members of this group are Mamodu S., Alpha T., Bernette K., John Roman K. and Lamin Foday. They are requesting a loan of US$ 1,700. They`ll use their loan either to give to their wives for their retail businesses or to buy building materials. As for John Roman K., he will use his to further educate himself. As monthly wage earners, these soldiers will be paying SMT through their paymaster.

loans.use: To give to  their wives to invest in their current businesses

loans.name: Tania

texts.es:
Mrs. Teresa is a member of the "Audacious Women" Communal Bank, located in Hr. Cacique Bolivar Mz.Q Lt.26, of the Yarina Cocha District, in the Ucayali Department. She is 30 years old, is the mother of 2 children, and her husband provides transportation services. With the first $100 loan Tania received from Manuela Ramos she invested in the purchase of snack foods.

Her business selling snacks and sweets is going well and she also have 3 motorcars that they were able to obtain thanks to the efforts of Tania and her husband. In the mornings she tends her business and in the afternoons works as a caretaker for a family. With this loan of $925, which will be repaid in 5 months, she will buy 2 boxes of snacks, sweets (cupcakes, etc.), 1 box of soft-drinks, 5 kg of gelatin, and a used motorcar.

Tania is very happy for the support she receives from Manuela Ramos which is why she puts so much hard work and dedication into her business.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Teresa pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Audaces, ubicado en el Jr. Cacique Bolívar Mz.Q Lt.26, del Distrito de Yarina Cocha del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 30 años es madre de 2 hijos, su esposo es Motokarrista. Tania con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertir en la compra de golosinas. Este negocio de golosinas le esta yendo bien y también cuenta con 3 motokar que pudieron obtenerlo gracias al esfuerzo que le pone Tania y su esposo. En las mañanas atiende su negocio y por las tardes trabaja como nana ayudando a una familia. Con este préstamo de S/ 2,700 el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará 2 cajas de pulpin, 2 queques 1 caja de gaseosa, 5 kg de gelatina y un motokar de segunda. Tania esta muy contenta por el apoyo que recibe de Manuela Ramos de tal manera le pone mucho empeño y dedicación a su negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of snacks at wholesale. Purchase of a used vehicle.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mrs. Mary L., 25 years old, is currently a housewife who stays home to care for children and cook for her husband. Her husband has a car that he drives as a taxi, earning approximately US $6.00 per day. They live in Ratanak Commune in the Battambang Province.

To increase her family's income, Mary wants to work outside of their home. She wants to run a business of selling clothes by going to customers' homes. Mary is requesting a loan of US$ 600 to use as capital to purchase used clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase used clothing to resell

loans.name: Gnagna

texts.fr: Gnagna F., 46 ans, mariée avec 05 enfants et 02 autres en charge est membre du banc villageois de Pire Gourèye depuis 7 ans. Elle veut renforcer son activité de vente de  produits divers (savon, sucre, lait, bougie, effets de toilette, etc.) dans une boutique. <b> Gnagna sollicite un  prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance. <b/>
texts.en:
Gnagna F. is 46 years old, married with 5 children and in charge of 2 others. She has been a member of the village bank Pire Gourèye for 7 years. She wants to strengthen her retail activity of various goods (soap, sugar, milk, candles, toiletries, etc.) in a store. Gnagna is asking for a loan that will be reimbursed at the end of 6 months in one single repayment.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of soap, sugar, milk, candles and toiletries to supply a shop

loans.name: Yao

texts.fr:
Né le 14 avril 1974, Monsieur K. Yao est marié et père de 2 enfans. Mécanicien de profession, voyant les revenus de sa profession insuffisant, il décide de joindre le transport en commun à l’aide d’une moto communément appelé Taxi moto qui est un secteur florissant dans notre économie à son activité principale. Pour réaliser ses ambitions, il sollicite un crédit afin d’acheter une moto et se relancer dans ce secteur de taxi moto.
Ceci l’aidera à accroître ses revenus ainsi il contribuera à améliorer les conditions de vie très misérables de sa famille.
texts.en:
Born on 14 April 1974, Mr. Yao K. is married and is the father of 2 children. A mechanic by profession, and seeing that the income from his job is insufficient, he has decided to go into public transportation with the help of a motorcycle, commonly called a Taxi moto. This is a flourishing sector in the local economy, and he intends to pursue this as his principal activity. To realize his ambitions, he is asking for a loan in order to buy a motorcycle and to launch himself in the motorcycle taxi sector. This will help him increase his income, and thus contribute to improving the miserable living conditions of his family.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy rice for her business.

loans.name: Teodolina

texts.es:
La señor Teodolina A.  tiene 48 años , tiene dos  hijos, mayores  no está casada ,  vive con sus hijos .  Hoy tiene su propio salón de masajes en su casa y también realiza esta trabajo a domicilio.
Hace mas de 20 años que se dedica a esta actividad y con su trabajo sacó adelante a sus hijos. Es una persona que ha progresado mucho en la vida y agradece a la Fundación Paraguaya por el apoyo que le ha brindado ya que hace mas de ocho años que trabaja con esta Institución.
Su deseo es seguir progresando y que sus hijos puedan lograr tener una educación superior.
texts.en:
Teodolina A. is 48 years old, is not married and lives with her two grown children. She operates her own therapeutic massage salon from her home, and also offers this service in the homes of her customers. She has worked in this field for more than 20 years, which has allowed her to support her children. She has achieved a lot in her life and is thankful for the support offered by Fundación Paraguaya. She was worked with this institution for more than eight years. She wishes to continue to build a better life for her family, and hopes her children can achieve a higher education.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase therapeutic massage products such as creams, oils, clothes and shoes for his business

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en: Zainabu M. is a Tanzanian business woman. She runs a business selling traditional clothes (Vitenge and Kanga) at Makangarawe ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the clothing from Mnazi mmoja traditional clothes shopping center and resells them to customers from her retail shop. She has been running this business for six years. Zainabu M. plans to run a wholesale shop. She is requesting a loan of Tshs. 600,000. ($450) to expand her business.

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Luk

texts.en: Luk Y. is 35 years old and lives with her husband in Siem Reap, Cambodia. She has made and sold charcoal since 2003. On average, she makes US$5 a day and her husband earns about US$3 a day cultivating rice. This couple has five children, three of whom attend school. Mrs. Luk Y. would like to take out a loan to purchase a small truck to transport her charcoal to sell in the market province.

loans.use: To purchase a small truck.

loans.name: Mehrovar

texts.en:
Mehrovar is a very ambitious young man with amazing selling skills. He is 20 years old, lives in Dushanbe, and has been working in the clothing industry for the past 3 years. He was able to expand his small business, over the year, into a well-known shop in the neighborhood.

Mehrovar is a very enterprising lad with a great desire to get ahead. His business has been able to show the fruits of his labor and he hopes to grow as a businessman. He needs a loan of 675 USD, which he plans to invest in inventory in order to offer better service and variety to his customers. You can be an important part of the growth of this business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing  new clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Tungalagtuya

texts.en:
Tungalagtuya B. lives with her husband and three children in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Their oldest son is a police officer at a local railway police station. Their oldest daughter is a student at a university and their youngest son is a fourth-grade student in a district high school.

In 2002, Tungalagtuya started running a small retail stall for handbags and women's apparel in the Hohburd market, one of the large markets in Ulaanbaatar. However, she was not making a stable profit in the Hohburd market and thus decided to move her business elsewhere. It has been about a year since she moved to the Norjin retail center. Her profits have been much better and her capital has increased since the move.

In the near future, Tungalagtuya would like to diversify her inventory and expand her stall space. Since the spring has just arrived, she requests a loan to purchase spring apparel from Beijing, China (it is very common for Mongolian small retailers to go to Beijing to purchase cheap apparel). In the future, she hopes to be able to buy a small house for her eldest son.

loans.use: To purchase spring apparel for resale

loans.name: Maria Fe

texts.en:
Maria Fe G. is 53 years old and a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative from Alegria, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is married and has 4 children. She is very industrious and takes great care raising her hogs while her husband is busy farming. Maria Fe personally manages their hog-raising business, which is doing well. She is a savvy business woman and the ups and downs of the business are normal to her. Sometimes they have business losses, sometimes a good return.

Now she sees a good opportunity to expand their business. She is requesting PHP 5,000 from Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative to buy animal feed and vitamins. She hopes deeply for a good education for her children and hopes to own a piggery someday.

loans.use: Purchase animal feed and vitamins

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
Antonia es socia del Banco Comunal Alianza
Antonia es conviviente, tiene 47 años y 2 hijos, Antonia viaja a la ciudad de Lima en donde adquiere huevo, papel higiénico y otros productos según la demanda, estos productos los vende al por mayor en la ciudad de Ayacucho.
Antonia necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de papel higiénico.
Antonia sueña con aumentar su negocio, su hijo culmine sus estudios y cambiar a otro negocio mas rentable.
texts.en:
Antonia is a member of the collective Banco Comunal Alianza. She is 47 years old and lives with her partner and two children. Her business entails traveling to Lima to buy eggs, toilet paper and other products in demand, which she sells in her city of Ayacucho. Antonia needs a 1200 soles loan, which she will use to buy toilet paper. Her dreams include having her own business, her son completing his studies, and switching to a more profitable business.

Translated from Spanish by Pamela Carreón, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy toilet paper (as merchandise)

loans.name: Juana Haydalina

texts.es: La señora Juana Haydelina Hernández, tiene la edad de 31 años, habita en el barrio buena Vista, ubicado en el municipio de nindiri, ella tiene dos hijos los cuales son adolescentes y estudian su secundaria, en sus tiempos libre el varón le apoya con los trabajos agrícolas y la mujer con las actividades del hogar, los planes hacia un futuro es mejorar las condiciones de vida y darles un mejor bienestar a su familia,  desde hace veinte años se dedica a los trabajos del campo , la mayor dificultad es la falta de financiamiento y las plagas que le afectan la producción , con el crédito obtenido va a comprar los insumos necesarios para aplicarle al cultivo  y obtener una mejor producción.
texts.en:
Mrs. Juana Haydalina H. is 31 years old and lives in the Buena Vista neighborhood, located in the municipality of Nindiri. She has two teenage children who are in high school. In their free time, her son helps her with the farm work and the daughter with the house chores. Her plans for the future are to improve their living conditions and provide better well-fare for her family. She has been working in farming for the last 20 years. Her major difficulties are the lack of financing and the pests that affect her production. With this loan that she is hoping to obtain, she will purchase the necessary supplies to apply to her harvest and therefore get a better yield.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies and fertilizers to apply to her crop.

loans.name: Razia Ilyas Group

texts.en:
This group loan will be distributed among 5 group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans, so that if one member does not repay, the other members are also responsible.

Khalida will use the loan to buy ready-made garments to sell. 
Ramzana will use it to buy tube lights to sell. 
Nazia will use it to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 
Musarat will use it to buy iron for making iron rods to sell.

Razia, the group leader, is a very hardworking lady. The other members respect her a lot for her good behavior. She operates a clothes sewing business by taking orders from her neighbors, while her husband works in a factory and receives a monthly wage. She will use the money from the loan to buy an electric sewing machine, so that she can sew more clothes and earn more income.

loans.use: To buy an electric sewing machine for sewing clothes

loans.name: Marling Aleyda

texts.es: Marling Aleyda es casada, de 28 años de edad, es Lic. En Admon. De Empresas, trabaja como secretaria en la Delegacion del MINED de Santo Tomas con 5 años de servicio, su esposo es Ing. Agronomo y trabaja en la Alcaldia de Santo Tomas, ambos aportan con los gastos del hogar, tienen un niño de 3 años, ella esta solicitando su primer credito el cual sera utilizado para mejorar su vivienda y terminar de contruir un muro para proteger la viivienda, porque con la lluvia esta erosionando y se le va a caer la casa, poir ese motivo desea hacer la inversion para evitar que el agua del invierno le destruya su vivienda, pues quiere garantizar la salud de su familia y la seguridad de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Marling Aleyda is 28-years old and married. She has a bachelor's degree in Business Administration and has served for 5 years as secretary of the Delegation of MINED in Santo Tomas. Her husband is an agronomist and works in the mayor's office in Santo Tomas. They both contribute their income to household expenses, and have a 3-year old son together. Marling is requesting her first loan which will be used to improve her home and finish constructing a wall to protect the house, because erosion caused by the rain could bury it. For this reason she wishes to invest in a way to prevent the water from destroying her house, assuring the health of her family and the safety of her home.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of wall

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica, a 50-year-old trader, is divorced and the mother of four children. Three of her children work and the fourth is in school. She is a very resourceful mother to her family. 

She supports her children through the sale of used clothing and shoes. Selling used clothing has a very big market in Ghana as brand new clothes are very expensive. Therefore selling used clothing has created a market for many Ghanaian women like Monica. 

She buys her stock of goods from the nearby city center called Kumasi; she started her business four years ago. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing and shoes to increase her inventory. She believes this loan would help her to save more for her children's education and also to rent a store to trade.

loans.use: To buy increased bales of used clothing.

loans.name: Nuufou

texts.en:
Nuufou V. is a 38-year-old woman living in the town of Vaovai. She is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Nuufou owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting taro for sale. Nuufou has been engaged in this business for over 4 years and earns approximately 360 WST a month from these activities.

In 2007, Nuufou joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nuufou has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1250 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. Nuufou is now requesting a new loan of 1250 WST, which will also be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. The loan will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Nuufou plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rsoe is 62 years old and married with 3 children. She sells jewelries and sarongs. Rose lives in Benin City and has been in business for long. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more jewelries and sarongs. She thanks all her kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and jewelries to sell

loans.name: Sousa Helena

texts.pt:
Sousa Helena M. nasceu na província de Maputo, distrito de Boane, tem 33 anos de idade, casado e pai de 2 filhos de doze e catorze anos de idades. Estudou ate 6 classe. Parou de estudar quando teve que começar a trabalhar e não consegue conciliar as duas actividades. Vive com a esposa e filhos na casa própria e ainda sustenta a sua mãe que vive na cidade de maputo. A esposa faz pequenos negócios para incremento da renda familiar.

Sousa nasceu, cresceu e vive em boane e é pedreiro profissional afecto na empresa publica de Administração Regional das Águas (ARA, sul) há mais de 14 anos e recebe mensalmente 2.452,00MT. Tem feito prestação de serviços de pedreiro para terceiros residentes da sua zona nos finais de semana, como forma de ganhar mais dinheiro.
Ganha de biscates cerca de 3.000,00MT por mês e ate consegue poupar algum dinheiro na sua conta bancaria.

Nunca teve créditos em outros bancos e este é o segundo empréstimo do Sousa na Hluvuku-Adsema no valor de 10.000,00MT para compra de material de construção de casa de alvenaria (cimento, pedra e barrotes). O primeiro credito foi de 6.000,00MT com o mesmo propósito.
Propõe se a pagar o empréstimo sem problemas para poder aceder a mais créditos. Quer ver a sua casa finalizada para sonhar em outros projectos.
texts.en:
Sousa Helena M. was born in Maputo, district of Boane, in Mozambique. He is 33 years old, married with two children aged 12 and 14. He finished 6th grade but had to drop school to get a job. He lives with his wife and children and supports his mother who lives in Maputo. His wife does some occasional work to help with household expenses. Sousa has been working as a construction worker for the same company for 14 years and makes 2.452,00MT (about U$90) per month. He also does construction jobs in the weekends for people in his neighborhood, in order to make more money. He makes around 3.000,00MT (about U$ 110) per month with freelance work and he is even able to save some money. This is Sousa's second loan from Hluvuku-Adsema, and he asks for $375 in order to buy construction supplies (cement, rocks). His first loan was in the amount of $218 for the same reason . He wants to finish his house so he can work in other projects.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction supplies (concrete, rock, sand)

loans.name: Flordelita

texts.en:
Flordelita N. is from the village of San Carlos, Tukuran, Zamboanga del sur. She is 45 years old and married with one school-aged child. To make a living, Flordelita owns and operates a retail "sari-sari" (variety) store. She sells food, candies and eggs in the local community. Flordelita has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $75 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Flordelita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flordelita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kitoy

texts.en:
Kitoy C. is currently in the business of selling sweets, biscuits etc at the shop and is requesting a loan to purchase plates and cups to sell.  Kitoy is 28 years old and is married to a soldier. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a department store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase  plates and cups to sell

loans.name: Leab

texts.en: Mr. Leab N. lives in Andoung village in Kandal province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. On this plantation, he faces a problem because the soil is infertile and he does not have rice seeds to plant in the field. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers, and rice seed. He will use the rest of money to buy pig food for his wife, Mrs. Ol Thavy, who is a pig breeder. She is also employed in a garment factory. Mr. Leab N. is 29 years old and the father of two children. One attends the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seed, and pig food.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 32 years old, married to Julius Gaitungu and they have three school-going children. She has been recycling metal and iron sheets to make products like grills, iron sheets for roofs, and water pipes for sale in Naivasha town for the last 10 years. Mary was introduced to KADET by her friend who is also a client. This will be her first loan and she plans to use the funding to buy raw materials to make the products which she sells. Her dream is to buy her own piece of land where she can make and sell her goods from. About KADET The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more metal (raw materials) for her business.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel B. is from the village of Isis. She is 49 years old. Maribel is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Maribel runs a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Maribel has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Maribel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maribel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC that she used to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. Maribel is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP to additional grocery stock for her sari-sari store, as well as livestock feed and other supplies for her secondary business, a piggery farm. This will be Maribel's 3rd loan from PMPC. She plans to save the additional revenue generated from the business for future emergencies and use for the education of her children. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase grocery stock and other supplies for secondary business

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 26 years old, is single, and he takes care of two dependents from his family. he lives in the Rulindo district, in the Northern Province of Rwanda that is approximately an hour’s drive from Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Joseph is a self-employed businessman selling different goods (cosmetics goods and some foodstuffs) in his retail shop. He has been in this business for more than three years and he works from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily.
 
Joseph is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase additional items like cosmetics goods and some foodstuffs such as sugar, biscuits, cooking oil, etc. With these additional items in his retail shop, Joseph hopes to earn more profits and improve on his savings as well as better providing for his extended family.

loans.use: To buy additional inventory for his store

loans.name: Nana

texts.en: Nana K. is married and has three children. She has no formal education.  Nana sells canned tomatoes and oil at Mrin Park near Elmina in Cape Coast. She has been doing this since 1995. Her husband is a driver.  Nana uses his income to pay school fees and utility bills. Nana will use the loan to buy gallons of oil and tomatoes for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Nana plans to save to buy land.

loans.use: To buy oil and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en:
Elisapeta T. is 37 and married with 4 children (ages 4-months - 10 years).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Elisapeta has 6 years of experience in this business.  Elisapeta needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase fertilizers such as manure.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 120 tala or US $50 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Elisapeta joined SPBD.    This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Elisapeta's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Elisapeta T. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.87 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.66 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

You can view pictures of a typical plantation in Samoa, taken by a Kiva Fellow, at:   http://picasaweb.google.com/agnes.p.chu/SamoanPlantation

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Lilibeth's Group

texts.en:
Lilibeth A. is from the village of Union, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 35 years old. Lilibeth is the group leader of a 17-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Lilibeth is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Lilibeth owns & operates a general store where she sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Lilibeth has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Lilibeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilibeth is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Lilibeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Gift

texts.en: Gift B. is 30 years old and married with 6 children. Her youngest child is 9 years old. Her children are still dependent on her and they go to school. Gift sells poultry to make a living in Sapele. She loves this business because it is highly profitable. She hopes for a loan amount of 80,000 to purchase more poultry to sell. Gift is a friendly woman and her friendliness attracts and retains customers. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry to sell.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is married with four children including a set of twins. All her children go to school. She rents a one-roomed house where she lives with seven people and doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has access to electricity and piped water at home and the family gets three meals a day.

Esther operates a retail shop in Mulago and that is how she earns a living. She works seven days a week and has done this business for four years now. She doesn’t incur any transport expenses as she lives near where she shops.

Esther receives about twenty customers a day and sells to all categories of people on a retail basis. Her monthly expenses include a license for the business premises, rent for her home and business, feeding the family, and school fees.

This is Esther’s third loan since she joined MCDT and she has been with MCDT for one-and-a-half years. She wants to use this loan to buy more home products for resale.

Esther is aspiring to seeing her business growing bigger and also starting a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to sell
