Gema is 52 years old.  She is married and has two children aged between 8 and 12 years old. She is commonly known for selling various goods such as drinks, bread, cosmetics, etc. This is her fifth successful year in this business.  Her business hours are from 7 am until 8 pm every day and she currently employs 3 people to help her.

Gema has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business by purchasing various goods such as drinks, bread, cosmetics, sugar, biscuits, etc. to sell.  With these additional goods, Gema will hopefully earn more profit, which in turn will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability and to provide all the basic needs for her family.

loans.use: buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Nabangala A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Nabangala A Group in Western Kenya! Sarah is the facilitator of the Nabangala group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Sarah takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Sarah had an excellent maize yield harvesting 10 bags on 3/4 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Sarah was only able to harvest 1.5 bags of maize on 3/4 acre of land. With income from maize sales, Sarah will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Sarah and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February, 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. In 2012, the members of Nabangala A group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

NB: Rachael Nabangala is funded in Nabangala B group; thus, this reduces the number in this group to three people.

loans.use: to source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Lani

texts.en: Lani is 41 years old and lives in the Philippines with her husband and two children. For the last seven years, she has earned a living by selling rice, and is applying for a loan for PHP 11,000 to buy more rice to sell to her customers. She has been a member of HSPFI since 2009 and is committed to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more rice to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.es: Marcelina de 42 años de edad convive con Jesús de 41 años, fruto de está relación tienen 3 hijos. Juntos habitan  en el distrito de la solidaridad, Pichari. Cuando Marcelina atravesaba los momentos más críticos de su vida, se presento una gran oportunidad de trabajo, que es en una acopiadora de cacao. Ahí se encarga de seleccionar  granos de cacao para luego empacarlos de 25 kilos cada uno y enviarlos a la capital para su comercialización. Marcelina lleva 8 meses laborando en esta acopiadora, donde recaudo un buen capital. Con ello empezó a realizar un negocio en la venta de prendas de vestir con la finalidad de tener un ingreso propio y así tener tiempo para su familia, ya que en el trabajo que tenía estaba sujeto a horarios. Ahora ella está feliz con el negocio que tiene, pues como aún desea crecer y no cuenta con capital suficiente recurre a MFP a solicitar un credito con el que ella desea a futuro contar con una tienda bien surtida de prendas. Este es su primer credito con MFP, por lo que se compromete en cancelar puntualmente en el pago de las cuotas. Con los 3,000 soles, comprará más prendas de vestir para abastecer su negocio.
texts.en:
Marcelina, 42, lives with Jesús, 41, and they have three children.  They all live together in La Soledad District, Pichari.  When Marcelina was going through some critical moments in her life a great work opportunity arose: a cocoa bean gathering center.  She selects cocoa beans there to be packaged in 25 kilo units and be sent to the capital to be sold.  Marcelina has been working for this gathering center for 8 months and has amassed a good capital.  

With it, she started a clothing sales business hoping to have her own source of income and have more time for her family because at work she had to follow work schedules.  Now, she’s happy with the business she has but since she still wants to grow and does not have sufficient capital to do so, she’s called on MFP to request a loan which she hopes will lead to a well-stocked clothing store in the future.  This is her first MFP loan and she commits to make her installment payments punctually.  She will use the 3000 soles to buy more articles of clothing to stock her business.

loans.use: to buy more articles of clothing.

loans.name: Lugari Farmer B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Lugari Farmer B Group in Western Kenya! Susan is the facilitator of the Lugari Farmer B group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Susan takes care of seven children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Susan had a good maize yield, harvesting 14 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Susan was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Susan and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Susan will educate her children and invest in business as future savings.

In 2012, the members of Lugari Farmer A group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows Susan with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en:
Benedicta is 57 years old and married with 8 children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell in her store.

She has borrowed and paid off 3 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running her store for 3 years and also earns an income from pig fattening. Benedicta aspires to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Arame Thiaw

texts.fr: Madame Arame vit au Sénégal depuis sa naissance. Elle est âgée  de 55 ans. Elle est veuve et exerce l’activité de femme de ménage depuis 20 ans.  Les raisons du choix de son  activité  est sa volonté de subvenir aux besoins de sa petite famille. Elle est sociétaire dans un des guichets de l’U-IMCEC  de la localité ou elle habite  depuis novembre 2003. Elle a déjà remboursé  9 prêts  antérieurs. Elle sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs prévu  pour la finition de la construction d’un appartement qu’elle avait entamé  chez elle.  Ses crédits antérieurs lui ont permis d’aménager sa maison  et de faire face aux dépenses de carrelage, de  dallage, d’électricité, de plomberie et  d’achats de portes et fenêtres. Son objectif est  d’améliorer  le confort et le cadre de vie de sa progéniture.
texts.en: Mrs. Arame has lived in Senegal since birth.  She is 55 years old. She is a widow and has been a cleaning lady for 20 years.  She chose her profession in order to provide for her small family.  She is a member of UIMCEC in the town where she has lived since November 2003.  She has already repaid 9 prior loans. She is asking for a loan of 500,000 francs to finish construction of an apartment that she had made her own.  Her prior loans have allowed her to move into her home and to cover the expenses of tile, flooring, electrical, plumbing, and the purchase of windows and doors.  Her goal is to improve the comfort and the quality of life of her children.

loans.use: to finish her apartment.

loans.name: Sarim

texts.en:
Sarim, 31, is married and resides with her husband and two school-aged children in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She and her husband are garment workers. 

In view of their meager income, Sarim would like to request a loan of USD 500 to run a new business by purchasing rice to store in the warehouse in order to sell it when the price is higher. By doing so, she will have extra income to support the family. In the future, she plans to purchase rice in large amount to store and resell when the price is higher. Moreover, she would like to build a bathroom and send her children to a good school.

loans.use: to purchase rice to store in the warehouse to sell when the price is higher.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Rola

texts.en:
Rola is 33 years old single woman, she lives in Al Hashmi- Amman, Jordan.
Rola is looking to have a loan of 500JDs thus she can sale car accessories.

loans.use: to sale car accessories

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 26 years old, married, and has two children who are in school. She sells cosmetics to earn a living. In the same business she also sells clothes. She has been in the business for two years and has employed one person. She also does pig farming to generate extra income. Through Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to save because she has been trained on financial management. She dreams of expanding her business and becoming successful in the future. She needs a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy cosmetics and clothes.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics and clothes.

loans.name: Dieu Est Grand Group

texts.fr: DIEU EST GRAND est un groupe composé de trois personnes qui sont des amies. Afin d'élever le niveau de leur activité, ce groupe sollicite l'appui financier de ALIDé. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Gilles Pulcherie (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) âgée de 46 ans, na pas fréquenté l'école. Gilles Pulcherie célibataire assure toute seule ses divers besoins. Pour ce faire, Gilles Pulcherie vend des tissus par la méthode de distribution depuis vingt un an, ce qui lui permet de mieux faire face aux besoins de ses enfants et à leur éducation. Gilles Pulcherie s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaire et son revenu, Gilles Pulcherie sollicite ensemble avec les membres du groupe DIEU EST GRAND, un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le crédit reçu antérieurement a été bien remboursé.

loans.use: Acheter des tissus.

loans.name: Flor De Encino Group

texts.en:
The area around the Western Highland town of Chichicastenango is filled with pine trees and the air smells fresh and delicious. Eight women have gathered together in a small rural community to form the Friendship Bridge Trust Bank “Flor de Encino”.  The ladies mainly have traditional textile businesses since there is a big demand for the colorful and ornate blouses called “huipiles”, woven skirts called “cortes” and table linens like napkins.

Catalina is the strong and energetic President of the Trust Bank. She is 55 years old, a mother of nine children who works hard to give her children all that she can. She was only able to stay in school until the 6th grade since times were economically tough when she was a child. Catalina has a traditional textile business and makes “huipiles”, as well as “cortes”. She greatly values the loans that she has received and is now requesting a new one to buy various colors and textures of thread as well as “cortes” to sell.

It has been traditional in the indigenous groups in Guatemala that girls stay in school for only a few years and then help out with household chores, as well as learn to weave. Approximately 80% of the ladies in the Trust Bank were unable to attend school.  They got married at an early age and had between four to nine children. They want to change the tradition that girls cannot go to school since they are keenly aware of the value of a good education. Fortunately, in their monthly meetings, they have the opportunity to participate in educational trainings conducted by a Facilitator from Friendship Bridge. They actively participate in games and role playing as they learn about self-esteem, women’s rights and how to set goals and realize their dreams. 

Catalina and the ladies of the “Flor de Encino” Trust Bank thank KIVA investors for funding their much-needed loans. Their success has such positive effects on their families and their community. Thank you!

loans.use: To buy various colors and textures of thread as well as “cortes” to sell.

loans.name: Sajida Parveen

texts.en:
Sajida is the age of 23 and a mother of one child living with her spouse and child in the area of Multan, Pakistan. She engages in dairy form to earn an income. She started her factory 4 years ago because she wanted to help her husband support the family and meet the household expenses. She has buffaloes and cows in her small dairy form that produce milk which she sells in her town. Her husband also helps in dairy form. Through breeding her buffalo, her husband has been increasing his herd over the years.
Sajida wants to buy cow for her dairy form to earn proper income but due to insufficient financial means she is unable to buy cow for her dairy form.  She has decided that she would like to increase the number of cow in her dairy form, so that she can earn better profit for her family. She has become an expert in dairy form. So, Sajida demanded a loan so she will be able to buy cow.
Sajida will be thankful to KIVA and field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy cow for her dairy form

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen A. is an active member of Life in Africa. He is a resident of Acholi quarters (a displaced people's camp in the surburb of Kampala). At the camp, his only source of income was the stone quarry where he worked very hard to make barely enough money to exist on. Since coming to Life in Africa, his life has totally changed.

He moved to Kampala as a result of the war in Northern Uganda. There he also was forced to live in an IDP camp and conditions were very hard. He had to leave school when he couldn't raise money for his school fees and his family had a hard time even getting enough food. He now lives with his brother and part of the money he earns he sends to his family back in Gulu to pay for school fees for his younger brothers and to help the family buy food.

His plan now is to start up a used clothing business. His brother has agreed to run the business while Stephen continues his work at Life in Africa. He plans to use the additional income from this business to start saving for building a family house that will enable him to bring down his family who are still suffering in the camps in northen Uganda.

For this business, he is seeking a loan in the amount of 500,000.

Below are his full budget:

1- 2 bales of clothes @ 150,000/= ------ 300,000/=

2- Transport ---------- 40,000/=

3- Rent for space @ 30,000/=@month ----- 90,000/=

4- licence --------- 50,000/=

5- contingencies ---------- 20,000/=

TOTAL ------------ 500,000/=
With the income he now earns through the WE Center Kampala, Stephen will be able to repay the loan in 12 months. He has designated 25% of the interest he pays to support the new Life in Africa WE Center in Gulu.

loans.use: Purchase 2 bales of second hand clothing and pay rent.

loans.name: Martine

texts.en:
Married to a farmer for ten years, Mrs. Martine T. does not have a very encouraging family life. At an early age she became involved in the business of selling doughnuts on the streets of her village. As a mother of three children, she receives practically no contribution from her husband towards the household expenses. Gifted and courageous, she holds out great hope of receiving a loan of $600, which will be used as business funds to stock up on wheat flour, oil and so on, for the preparation and sale of doughnuts. This will allow Mrs. T. to increase production, and have several sales outlets in the businesses and markets of her village so that she can increase her turnover and her income.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer.

Mariée depuis une dizaine d’années à un cultivateur, Madame T. Martine n’a pas une situation familiale favorable à un épanouissement. Très tôt, elle s’est lancée dans le commerce de la vente des beignets à travers les artères de sa localité. Mère de trois (3) enfants, elle ne bénéficie pratiquement pas de contribution de son mari aux charges du ménage. Très douée et courageuse, elle espère vivement avoir un apport financier de $600 qui va lui servir de fonds de commerce pour faire un stock de la farine de blé, d’huile, etc. en vue de la préparation et la vente des beignets. Ceci lui d’augmenter sa production et avoir plusieurs points de vente dans les établissements et marchés de sa localité afin d’accroître son chiffre d’affaire et son revenu.

loans.use: To stock up with wheat flour for the preparation and sale of doughnuts

loans.name: Bernice

texts.en: Mama A. has been a client of Kraban Support Foundation for years now. She has had several training sessions on simple record keeping and loan management from the organization. She sells provisions in Nkurankan, Ghana where she lives. She is seeking a loan of US$850.00 from Kiva to help her expand her shop.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.es:
Magdalena is 32 years old. She is married with 7 children. Her husband works in the fields. She makes embroidered artisanal products and she also has a small grocery shop in her house. She hopes to invest half of the loan in the purchase of thread and fabric for the artisanal products and the other half in the purchase of merchandise for the store (rice, oil, pastas). This way she can increase her income. She belongs to the group Rosas 4.

Translated by Bianca Vargas, Kiva Volunteer.

MAGDALENA TIENE 32 AÑOS , CASADA , TIENE 7 HIJOS , SU ESPOSO TRABAJA EN EL CAMPO . ELLA SE DEDICA A LA CONFECCION DE PRENDAS ARTESANALES Y BORDAR , TAMBIEN TIENE UNA PEQUEÑA TIENDITA DE ABARROTES EN SU CASA .ESPERA CON EL PRESTAMO INVERTIR LA MITAD EN LA COMPRA DE HILOS Y MANTA PARA LA CONFECCION DE SUS PRENDAS Y LA OTRA MITAD COMPRAR MERCADERIA ( ARROZ, ACEITE, PASTAS ) PARA SU TIENDITA Y ASI AUMENTAR SUS INGRESOS . PERTENECE AL GRUPO ROSAS 4.

loans.use: Artisan sales and grocery store.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Mrs. Juliet U. sells clothes, bags & shoes.  She is 25 years old, and married with 6 children.  She started her business in 2005.  She is also a LAPO client.  She is requesting for the loan above to buy more clothes, bags and shoes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothes, bags & shoes to sell

loans.name: Lupe

texts.en: Lupe is a 48-year-old mother of two. Her business is running a flea market stall. She sells handicrafts in front of her house and at a stall at the Savalalo market. She makes $100-150 a day from selling handicrafts, and she uses her earnings to help support her family.

loans.use: To buy supplies and inventory for her flea market stall

loans.name: Sophat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophat K. married in 1999 and has three sons. She learned to weave silk from a neighboring villager in 1987 and started her silk production in the same year. Her husband is a construction worker and is currently doing farming, raising animals, and also driving a horse cart when he has enough time. They both did not finish high school. Sophat and her husband try to work hard for a bright future for their children.

Mrs. Sophat K. has borrowed money from MAXIMA four times already. Now she is asking for a loan in the amount of US$ 100. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials and sewing thread.

loans.use: Purchasing silk materials and sewing thread

loans.name: Gemilda Arcelli

texts.es:
Gemilda is a member of the community bank La Mujer Riojana. She has an upholstery business on Tupac Amru Cdra Street in the town of Rioja in the province of Rioja in the San Martín region of Peru. She is the manager and owner of her business, with 2 of her children and several additional employees delivering the service under her direction.

With the loan of 3000 soles (Peruvian currency), which she will repay in 6 months, Gemilda will buy leather coverings of different colors (6 bundles), a sewing machine for thick fabrics, 4 cans of glue, 4 spools of nylon thread, 2 pairs of steel scissors and other materials that her employees request of her.

With the support of her children Gemilda has been able to move her business ahead. She is always paying attention to the materials that she lacks and the people she needs to meet her orders, along with the quality of the final products, so that her clients will continue to recommend her.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Gemilda es socia del banco comunal La Mujer Riojana, tiene un negocio de tapizados en el Jr. Tupac Amaru Cdra 1 en la localidad de Rioja, provincia de Rioja, región San Martín en la cual es la administradora y propietaria, dos de sus hijos y personal a su cargo son los que brindan el servicio directo del negocio.

Con el préstamo de S/. 3,000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará marroquines de distintos colores (06 fardos), una máquina de coser para tela gruesa, cuatro latas de pegamento, cuatro ovillos de hilo nylon, dos tijeras de acero y otros materiales necesarios que le vayan solicitando.

Con el apoyo de sus hijos ha podido sacar adelante su negocio. Siempre está pendiente de los materiales que faltan y del personal que necesite, también de los acabados de los trabajos para dar una mejor presentación y puedan seguir recomendándolos.

loans.use: Purchase of materials for upholstery of furniture and purchase of assets (sewing machine)

loans.name: Loumossi

texts.fr:
Born in 1982, Mrs. Loumossi B. is married and mother of three children. Selling beans is her primary business activity. She begins work very early in the morning. Nowadays, dried beans are becoming more and more expensive. To be protected from price surges, Mrs. B. is asking for a loan in the amount of US$ 250 to purchase some sacks of dried beans, as well as the condiments she needs to satisfy the demand of her customers. The income from her expanded business will permit her to support her family better.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Née en 1982, Madame B. Loumossi est mariée et mère de trois (03) enfants. La vente du haricot est sa principale activité. Très tôt le matin, elle vaque librement à ses occupations. Aujourd’hui, cette céréale devient de plus en plus cher. Pour être à l’abri de la flambée du prix, Madame B. Loumossi sollicite un financement de $250 pour s’acheter des sacs de haricot, et autres compléments afin de satisfaire sa clientèle. Les bénéfices issus de la vente lui serviront à mieux subvenir aux charges de son ménage.

loans.use:
Purchase of dried beans

Achat et vente d'haricot

loans.name: Graciela

texts.en:
Graciela Ester F. is a mother of two. She runs a small grocery store in Ciudad del Este. She has been in business for 6 years and her income, along with her husband’s income for construction work, is enough to support the family. She would like to see her grocery store prosper but can only do so with a small loan.

Graciela would like a loan of $425 to buy more stock for her store including more foodstuffs like sugar, oil, eggs, and milk. Her husband at times goes into the bordering country of Brazil to buy cheaper goods. This loan will help their business and their humble incomes grow, and help to put their children through school.

loans.use: To buy food merchandise like sugar, eggs, milk, meat, and pasta for resale

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun S., 53, and her husband, Vuthy Chok, married in 1975. They have seven children; four sons and three daughters. Two of their children are married and live in the family house. The family lives on Koh Dach Island on the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Saroeun is in the business of weaving silk. She learned weaving from her mother and started her silk production business in 1979. She sells her finished products in her village. Her husband is a teacher.

Mrs. S. is requesting a loan for the third time in the amount of $200 to purchase silk material for weaving. Based on her business success so far, she will have no problem in repaying the loan to MAXIMA.

loans.use: For purchasing silk material for weaving

loans.name: Josephine's Group

texts.en:
Josephine N. has been married for 36 years and is a mother of seven: four boys and three girls. All her daughters and the eldest son are married. Josephine’s husband works at a medical laboratory and one of her sons provides movie-making services at various occasions including weddings and birthdays. Currently, her son wants to purchase a new camera for which he needs a loan. Josephine will save the extra profits from his income for his wedding.

There are several other women in this loan group who also require small loans: Tahira Y. needs her share of the loan for her husband’s medical laboratory; Razia J.’s daughter runs a beauty salon. Suriya S. will invest her share of the group loan in her husband’s grocery store, and Sakina S.’s son runs a medical laboratory. All these women have been together for a year and practice values such as punctuality and saving.

loans.use: Buy a new movie camera for her son's business

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
Francisca is a humble and self-assured woman. For as long as she can remember, she has seen the necessity of working and earning her own income. Currently, with diligence and dedication, she is engaged in two activities, the weaving of gorgeous caps and scarves that she sells in the Sunday market in Juliaca and the selling of American-style clothing and stuffed animals. With these two business she is managing to get ahead and provide an education for her little daughter, Cristina, for whom she has the dream of some day building a house in order to live in the security and warmth of her own home.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer.

Francisca, es una mujer humilde y segura de sí misma, desde que tuvo uso de razón se vio en la necesidad de trabajar y generar sus propios ingresos económicos, actualmente con diligencia y disciplina viene dedicándose a dos actividades, al tejido de hermosas gorras, chullos y chalinas que comercializa en el mercado dominical de la ciudad de Juliaca; al mismo tiempo al negocio de venta de ropas y peluches americanos.Con estos dos negocios está logrando salir adelante y ofrecerle educación a su pequeña niña, Cristina, con quien sueña algún día construir su morada y vivir bajo la seguridad y el calor de su propio hogar.

loans.use: Increasing her business capital in order to offer more products

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 40 year-old Grace S.. She is married and has four children aged between 7 months and 18 years. In 2007, Grace established her traditional African cloth business. Working six days a week, 13 to 16 hours a day, she earns about US $20 every month from this business. She is assisted by her husband and one employee.

Grace requires a loan in order to expand her shop and purchase additional stocks of traditional cloth and sarongs. In the future, Grace plans to open another business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of traditional African cloth and sarongs in bulk.

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha has been selling fast food for a long time. At 32 years of age, she has demonstrated that she is a proactive woman who spreads joy to those who know her. By means of her job, she has been able to move her 5 children forward, and they in turn take the fullest advantage of getting ahead. Martha is a woman with the desire for self-improvement. As a result, she wants to expand and develop her business because it is located in a commercial zone. She has the support of her husband, Segundo, who helps her out a great deal in her business. However, in order to reach her objective—having a kiosk made that will better welcome her patrons—she needs a sum of money to invest in her business, thus fulfilling the plans that she has laid out.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Martha se dedica a la venta de comida desde hace mucho tiempo, a sus 32 años demuestra ser una mujer proactiva que contagia alegría a todo aquel que la conoce. Mediante su trabajo está sacando adelante a sus 5 hijos, quienes aprovechan lo máximo para salir adelante. Martha es una mujer con deseos de superación, pues ella quiere ampliar e implementar su negocio puesto que se encuentra ubicada en una zona comercial. Ella cuenta con el apoyo incondicional de Segundo, su esposo, quien la apoya mucho en este su negocio. Sin embargo, para cumplir su objetivo, mandar a construir un kiosco para dar una mejor acogida a sus clientes, ella estima de una cantidad de dinero que invertirá en su negocio y de esta manera cumplir con su meta trazada.

loans.use: Have a kiosk made in order to improve customer service

loans.name: Chanthou

texts.en:
Chanthou P. grows rice and vegetables on her farmland in Phteah Prey Commune, Pursat Province. She has been growing rice since 1993 and earns approximately $1.50 per day. She is married and has four children, all young and in school. Chanthou and her husband work hard every day due to increasing family expenses.

Because her farmland is infertile, she needs to use fertilizer to increase her rice yield. She faces the obstacle of a lack of money, so she decided to request a loan to purchase fertilizer. She hopes to increase her rice yield using the loan. In the picture, Chanthou, her husband, and her children are growing rice.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Sneg

texts.en:
Mrs. Sneg P., a farmer in Smaonh Village in Kampong Cham Province, cultivates both rice and vegetables. Since these fields are too large for her to work alone, she is requesting a loan to hire laborers and buy fertilizers for those fields. 

Sneg is 29 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are attending school while the other two are of preschool age. Her husband, Mr. Yorn Chamrong, shown on the left in the photo, is a security guard.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work the field and buy fertilizers to support those fields.

loans.name: Soedinou

texts.fr:
Né à Agbodrafo en 1974 Mr A. Soedinou est marié et père de 03 enfants. Il a quitté très tôt les bancs de l’école  car ses parents ne pouvaient plus supporter les frais de l’écolage. Le métier de menuiserie qu’il a apprit lui a permis de vivre jusqu’alors.
       
Sa famille étant grandissante il n’arrive plus à subvenir à leurs besoins essentiels .Le commerce de planches étant une activité qui rapporte beaucoup en ce moment, il décida de se lancer dedans afin  de pouvoir joindre les deux bouts.
        
Il sollicite alors un crédit pour l’achat et vente de planches. Cela lui permettra certainement d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Born in Agbodrafo in 1974, Mr. Soedinou A. is a married father of three. He quit school very early, because his parents weren’t able to pay for his schooling. He learned woodworking, which has been his livelihood. He is no longer able to provide for the essential needs of his growing family. The business of selling planks is currently strong, and he has decided to get into this business to be able to join the two ends. He seeks this loan to buy and sell planks. This will certainly allow him to improve the conditions of his family’s life.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy and sell planks

loans.name: Damarys Johanna

texts.es: La Sra. Damaris habita en un barrio de la capital que se llama Laureles Norte, desde su juventud, tiene 32 años de edad, con un niño de 7 años de edad que esta estudiando la primaria, su esposo trabaja como albañil por cuenta propia, y abecés por contrato es un trabajo muy agotado pero se gana bien, doña Damaris trabaja en servicios domésticos desde hace dos años, pues se le había dificultado encontrar trabajo ya que las plazas están llena. Con la solicitud de préstamo lo quiere para infraestructura para levantar dos paredes de su vivienda e ir quitando las paredes de madera que tiene actualmente para esto va a comprar piedra, arena, cemento y hierro. Su mayor anhelo es poder tener una vivienda digna donde pueda tener seguridad su familia,  ya que su vivienda es muy humilde pero gracias al  préstamo que AFODENIC le ha otorgado desea poder ver sus casa terminada.
texts.en:
Damaris lives in a city neighborhood called Laureles Norte, where she has lived since she was young. She is 32 years old and has a 7-year old child who is in primary school. Her husband is self-employed as a construction worker, and he sometimes works on contract. It is hard work but brings good earnings. Damaris has worked as a housekeeper for two years, since she had trouble finding other work due to few opportunities. With the request for a loan, she would like to fix the infrastructure in her home to build two new walls and take out the wood ones that she currently has. To do this, she will buy stone, sand, cement and iron. Her greatest wish is to have a dignified home where her family can live securely, given that her dwelling is very humble but thanks to the loan that AFODENIC granted she hopes to see it completed.


Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to build two walls.

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Mr. Kong B. is a villager in Hang Heng village in Takeo Province. He is a construction worker. His wife, Mrs. Phuong Kunthea, is employed in a garment factory. Since their workplaces are far from their house, they usually pay a lot of money for motorbike taxi transport. 

Thus, Mr. Kong B. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike to travel to work in order to reduce his expenses. He is 26 years old and the father of two children who are too young to work or study. His wife and daughter are shown with him in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to travel to work

loans.name: Morl

texts.en: Morl S. is 28 years old and a resident of Pursat Province where she lives with her husband and their young child. Her child is a minor and attends school. She is married to Yem Phary who is 33 years old. The couple are local farmers and make a living by growing rice. They currently earn a revenue of approximately $4 a day, and they are both widely known for their business experience. Cultivating rice is their main way of earning income and they always hire the neighbors water buffalo to help their farm work. They now want to own their own buffalo and are requesting a loan to purchase two water buffalo. The loan will help their family by reducing their farming expenses.

loans.use: to purchase two water buffalo

loans.name: Las Tiluchis Group

texts.es: LOS SOCIOS (AS) QUIENES CONFORMAN EL GRUPO "LAS TILUCHIS" SON PERSONAS RESPONSABLES Y MUY EMPRENDEDORAS COMO LO DEMOSTRARON EN UN ANTERIOR FINANCIAMIENTO CON LA FUNDACIÓN AGROCAPITAL YA QUE CURSAN SU SEGUNDO CICLO CON RESPONSABILIDAD Y HONESTIDAD, ESTÁN REPRESENTADAS POR LA SEÑORA BEATRIZ QUIEN ES LA PRESIDENTA DEL GRUPO. EN GENERAL LAS SOCIAS SE DEDICAN AL COMERCIO D. DIFERENTES PRODUCTOS COMO COSMÉTICOS, CAJAS, COMIDA Y A LA PRESTACIÓN D. SERVICIOS COMO ESTILISTAS, CONTADORES, CARPINTERÍA Y ALA ELABORACIÓN D. PAN. DENTRO DEL ÁMBITO LABORAL EXISTE MUCHA COMPETENCIA PERO DEPEND. D. CADA UNA EL MEJORAR SU PRODUCTO A LA VENTA CON MEJORES MATERIALES E INSUMOS Y A MEJORAR SUS HERRAMIENTAS D. TRABAJO PARA BRINDAR UN MEJOR SERVICIO, ES PARA ESTO QUE REQUIEREN D. FINANCIAMIENTO PARA LA ADQUISICIÓN D. INSUMOS MATERIALES Y HERRAMIENTAS D. TRABAJO PARA INCREMENTAR SUS INGRESOS Y MEJORAR SU CALIDAD D. VIDA Y LA D. SUS FAMILIAS.
texts.en:
The members who form the "Las Tiluchis" group are responsible and very enterprising people which they demonstrated in a previous financing with the Agrocapital Foundation now that they are in their second funding with responsibility and honesty, they are represented by Beatriz, who is the president of the group. In general the member are dedicated to selling different products like cosmetics, boxes, food and the presentation of services like stylists, contractors, carpenters, and to making bread. Within the work environment there is a lot of competence, but each depends on improving her products with better materials and products and improving her tools to achieve a better service, which is why they require financing for the acquisition of materials and tools to increase their earnings and improve their standards of living, along with their families'.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Sabougnouma sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 37ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent en majorité dans les  familles traditionnelles polygames à TDJILA situé dans la sous préfecture de NIENA de la 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles menent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres l’achat – vente de céréales, de condiments alimentaires, de canaris et  la restauration.
Elles sont à leur premier prêt (prêt solidaire) qu’elles comptent utiliser pour acheter, 7sacs de 100kg de céréales, 18 canaris, 200 kilo de grains de Néré pour le soumbala et des condiments alimentaires pour la restauration.
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de NIENA, et de BOUGOULABA. Les marchandises sont vendues aux marchés de NIENA, de BOUGOULABA, et de TDJILA en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 5 750 FCFA par mois dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie  investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the group Sabougnouma are all married and average 37 years of age and 4 children. Most of them live in traditional polygamous families in TDJILA, located in NIENA sub-prefecture (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They do a variety of work, including the buying and selling of grain, condiments, and canaris (pottery containers) and the catering of food.

The women are on their first loan (solidarity loan), which they plan on using to buy seven 100-kg sacks of grain, 18 canaris, 200 kg of Néré seeds for making

soumbala, and condiments for preparing meals. Supplies are gotten at the markets of NIENA and BOUGOULABA. The goods are sold at the markets of NIENA, BOUGOULABA, and TDJILA at the retail level and in cash, to customers composed of men and women.

The group members each envision realizing an average profit of 5,750 francs CFA per month that will be used in part for family needs and the rest, for investing in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Fatima

texts.fr:
O. Fatima est née vers 1966. Fatima est mariée et mère de quatre 4 enfants: deux sont scolarisés et les deux autres sont en apprentissage. Fatima vend de la nourriture au quartier Saint-Martin, non loin de la perception, à proximité de son domicile. Fatima est à son quatrième crédit avec ALIDé et à son deuxième crédit avec Kiva. Fatima a pu développer et maintenir son activité de restauration grâce différents prêts qu'elle a eu de ALIDé et de Kiva. Fatima sollicite encore de  crédit pour développer un peu plus son entreprise de restauration populaire afin de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle de façon conséquente. 

p> 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
O. Fatima was born around 1966. She is married and the mother of four children: two are in school, and the other two are in apprenticeships. She sells food in the Saint-Martin district, not far from the tax collector's office and near her home. Fatima is on her fourth loan with ALIDE and her second loan with KIVA. She was able to develop and maintain her restaurant business, thanks to different loans she had with ALIDE and with KIVA. She's requesting a loan again in order to develop her popular restaurant enterprise a little more. The demand from her customers may then be satisfied substantially.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 2 sacks of rice, 3 boxes of pasta (macaroni), 10 liters of peanut oil, and also some condiments

loans.name: Kosar

texts.en: Kosar baji is the wife of M. A. and has lived in a mid-sized city named Riwind in Pakistan for the last ten years. Her husband runs a dairy business. He has six years of experience in this business. Currently, he owns one buffalo.  Kosar baji and her husband get up at 4:00 am, milk the buffalo and fill milk pots. After that, M. A. goes to the milk shops to sell the milk. Kosar baji is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo to expand the dairy business.

loans.use: to buy another buffalo for dairy business

loans.name: Kikiafu 3 Group Amina Ali

texts.en:
A. Ali is married with five children, three of them in school. She owns a hairdressing salon for cutting and shaving hair. She is using the loan to purchase salon equipments like shavers, a fan, and combs.

She is thinking of starting another hairdressing salon specifically for ladies.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for her hairdressing salon

loans.name: Lucy

texts.es:
Lucy es socia del Banco Comunal Virgen Maria.
Lucy es soltera, tiene 22 años y vive con padres, Lucy viaja a las ferias de la region en donde compra cereales, papa, queso, animales menores, productos que vende en la feria de San Juan y también de casa en casa.
Lucy necesita un préstamo de 1600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de ganado vacuno.
Los sueños de Lucy es comprar un establo para engordar animales y estudiar la carrera de medicina veterinaria.
texts.en:
Lucy is a member of the Virgin Mary Communal Bank. She is single, 22 years old, and lives with her parents. Lucy travels to the regional markets where she buys cereals, potatoes, cheese, and baby animals. She sells these products in the San Juan market and also door-to-door. Lucy needs a loan of 1600 soles that she will invest in the purchase of cattle. Lucy's dream is to purchase a stable for fattening animals and to study veterinary medicine.

Translated from Spanish by Leah Karlins, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Vergie

texts.en:
Vergie P. is from the village of Segatic Daku Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Vergie raises crops, primarily from planting and harvesting corn and bananas for sale. Vergie has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Vergie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting her first GDMPC loan of 8000 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business and pay for her children's education.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Vilayat

texts.en:
Selling cosmetics and home products in his private shop became the only source of income for Vilayat K., a 50-year-old man who's been doing this for fifteen years. He is married and the father of one son. His child is the reason that he works hard in order to provide him with the best and brightest future.

This man has many projects for his future. Vilayat’s wish is to add more cosmetics and therefore have more to offer to his clients. He would pay back this loan and, also with the profits, he would be able to pay for his son’s wedding. This man waits for your help. Let's make his dream come true.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Toalima

texts.en: Toalima H., age 30, is married and has three children. She has many years of experience in the farming business.  She sells to the general public 6 days per week.  She has had one previous loan from SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala.  SPBD loans are Toalima’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used to pay her children's school fees. Her husband works at Yazaki to earn extra income.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals such as pesticides, weed killer, fertilizers, gromozones, and bush knives.

loans.name: Diapo Pointe Sarrène Group

texts.fr: Nous avons décidé de créer un groupe restreint pour pouvoir mettre sur pied une entreprise durable avec un nombre limité de 05membres. Nous voulons faire du commerce de produits halieutiques que nous comptons acheter chez les producteurs , les transformer et ensuite les revendre en ville ou dans les marchés hebdomadaires qui s'organisent toutes les semaines autour de notre village, dans les hôtels de la région comme Pointe Sarrène est un site touristique , mais aussi dans les grandes villes du Sénégal. Ce financement nous permettra de faire des économies pour subvenir à nos besoins et ceux de nos familles.
texts.en:
We have decided to create a limited group to be able to establish a lasting enterprise with a membership limited to five. We want to do commerce in seafood products that we intend to buy from producers, to process, and then to resell in town or in the weekly markets that are organized every week around our village and in regional hotels, such as Pointe Sarrène, a tourist site, and also in the big cities in Senegal.  This financing will allow us to save some money to provide for our needs and those of our families.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To process and trade in seafood products

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is already 56 years old. She is married to Paulino who is 68 years old and works as a simple farmer in their village. They are gifted with three children and they are so grateful because all of their children were able to finish their college education and are now working. Sometimes, their children assist them financially but Cristina does not want to depend too much on their children for their needs.

Cristina manages a village store and sells vegetables. She is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 15,000 as additional capital to further improve her simple enterprise hoping to eventually have an increase in income. She also wants her hog-raising business to be stable by maintaining their feed supply. She really wants to improve her sales to create a good income.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Hazel

texts.en:
Hazel A. is from the village of Lurugan, Valencia City. She is 36 years old and married. To make a living, Hazel owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, where she sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Hazel has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Hazel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hazel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Hazel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Hazel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the product offering at her general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase general food items.

loans.name: Sou

texts.en: Sou C. is 33 years old and resides with her husband in Siem Reap province. She and her husband, Van Vat, are local teachers, typically making about US$ 2 every day. This couple has two children living at home to support. Sou C. is asking for a loan of US$ 600 to fix her leaking roof. (Her husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To fix her leaking roof

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita V. is married to a farmer named Carlos V.. She is selling vegetables in different barangays near in their village using their motorcycle. They are blessed with seven children. Five are presently studying and taking their education. According to her, even farming is their source of income, their trying their best and keep on working just to give their children a good education. With their dreams to finish all their children's studies, they do everything that will help them to attain their dreams. Even they are feeling hot under the heat of the sun and feel the coldness during rainy season, they still working in fields to support the general needs of their family. 

When time of harvesting and selling their products in fields, their income is not enough to support their children's expenditures in school. Lolita wanted to borrow the amount of Php 15,000 for additional capital to buy additional vegetables to sell.  Her profit will be a great help to provide all her children expenditures in school for the whole school year.

loans.use: additional capital to buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria is a 58 year widow, with eight children, aged between 24 and 38 years.  None of her children goes to school. She resides and owns a two room house where she is staying with five people .The family has access to electricity but no piped water.  Victoria takes care of additional family members.  She owns a piggery farm at her home in Ndeeba Kigaga Zone and pays for transport costs to and from shopping for feed.  On average she receives about  3 customers a day. She works in the out skirts of Kampala. She has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for six years. She is servicing  her 7th loan. Her main business challanges include defaulters and thieves. Victoria  wants to use this loan to buy more bags of  feeds and piglets She aspires to see her business grow stronger and hopes to start buying feed directly from producers.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and piglets

loans.name: Clement

texts.en:
Clement C. is currently in the business of purchasing and selling bread and is requesting a loan to buy more goods, such as sugar, maize flour and millet flour to sell.  Clement is 35 years old and is divorced.   She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a new house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Nelda

texts.en:
Nelda M. is from the village of Anito, which is within the Mambajao Camiguin Province of the Philippines. She is a 46-year-old single woman with one school-age child. To earn a living, Nelda owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector; more specifically, she runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Her main source of income is derived from selling both food and everyday products to her local community members. Nelda explains that she has been engaged in this business for over 12 years, and that she typically earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2008, Nelda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services; as a result, she was able to engage in business activities, and, in turn, to improve her family's standard of living. Importantly, Nelda has already successfully repaid a previous loan from HSPFI in the amount of 14,000 PHP, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. In fact, the loan that she is now requesting would be the fifth loan taken out by Nelda from HSPFI. Indeed, Nelda is now seeking another loan from HSPFI, this time in the amount of 15,000 PHP ($325), which will again be used to purchase additional products for resale purposes. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City, and its mission is to assist the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional products

loans.name: Fatmeh

texts.en: Fatmeh has worked as a home-based hairdresser since 2005 to help her husband in the household. Today, Fatmeh is asking to borrow $US1,000 to purchase cosmetics and appliances needed for her business.

loans.use: To  purchase cosmetics and appliances for her business.

loans.name: Jose

texts.es: José de 64 años, es un hombre muy emprendedor que comparte su vida con su esposa Sabina y sus hijos Aldo (17) y Fernando (11), en su casa que es propia.Junto con su compañera de toda la vida  trabaja  en un pequeño puesto en el mercado Villa Estela (uno de los más concurridos del Balneario de Ancón), su esposa se dedica a la venta de pollo, y José a la venta de condimentos, en el mismo sitio, pero usualmente la que permanece más tiempo en el negocio es Sabina, ya que él  debe trasladarse hasta el centro de la ciudad para comprar la mercadería al por mayor para venderla después en su puesto. A los dos  les gusta mucho su trabajo y son muy cordiales con el trato al cliente ,es por esta razón que tienen gran cantidad de demanda, de otro lado ambos  esperan seguir mejorando y en un futuro ampliar el negocio para comprar  más cantidad de mercadería para así llegar a satisfacer todas las necesidades de la clientela y mejorar los ingresos familiares.Es su sétimo crédito con  MFP y siempre han sido muy puntuales y responsables en cada pago.Con el dinero del préstamo abastecerán su negocio con mayor cantidad de mercadería entre  condimentos y pollos para de esta manera  aumentar sus ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
Jose a very enterprising 64 year old man who shares his life with his wife, Sabina, and his sons, Aldo (17) and Fernando (11). He and his life partner work in a small stall in the Villa Estrella marketplace (one of the most well-known in the Balneario de Ancon neighborhood). His wife sells chicken and he sells condiments in the same location, but Sabina spends more time working the business, since he needs to travel to the city center to buy merchandise to resell from their stall. They both like their work very much and they treat their customers very well. This is why they have so many requests from them. They both hope to continue to improve their lives and be able to expand their business and be able to buy greater quantities of merchandise to be able to satisfy all of their customers’ need and increase their income. This is their seventh loan through MFP and they have always been responsible and on time with their payments. They will use the money from this loan to stock their business with more merchandise, chicken and condiments, to be able to improve their income.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food products for resale

loans.name: Katerina

texts.en:
Katerina E. is 29 and married with 2 children (ages 2 and 6).  She is starting a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Katerina needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 100 tala or US $42 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Katerina joined SPBD.    This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Katerina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Katerina E. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                2 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2.1 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.99 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.89 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en: 35-year-old Geraldine is a married woman with three children. Her oldest child is now 16 years old. She is involved in rice farming. She works hard to make her farm productive. She wants to double her harvest in order to be able to earn more money.   She wants to be able to better provide for the growing needs in her household. She is seeking a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos, which she plans to use to buy fertilizer and other farming supplies.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other farming supplies

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine has been selling groceries for three years. She loves her business because her customers pay in cash when they come to purchase groceries. She does not sell on credit to her customers. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She hopes to own a world-class supermarket in the future. 

Josephine is 45 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a tailor and he also supports the home. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organisation) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and else where in Africa.  Josephine says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en: “I manage 2 hectares of rice field, and I was also able to start a small store to have an extra source of income," shares Cristina, an entrepreneur from Trento, Agusan Del Sur. At 53, she now has four children with her husband, Somy. Both of them agree that their children’s education should be a top priority. Cristina helps Somy maintain their rice field. She needs additional capital, so she applied to CEVI and asked for a loan of 5,000 PHP. With this amount, Cristina can buy seeds, fertilizers, and other farm supplies she needs.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Mrs. Savry Shum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Thirteen people who all live in Kampong Svay Leu village in Kandal province have made up this village bank loan. Mrs. Savry S. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members. They will each use their loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Savry S. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice on to support her family. She is a mother of a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Bory Koev, is a cigarette seller who can earn only a little money to buy some piglets for breeding to start a new business.

loans.use: To buy some piglets for breeding

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.es: La señora Esperanza de edad de 49 años, vive en el barrio Hialeah, su negocio es la venta de ropa, zapatos, chinelas que desde hace varios años  vende para poder ayudar a su familia, ya que su esposo su salario es bajo, el trabaja en servicio de seguridad y es mal pagado. Para doña Esperanza ha sido difícil ya que aun no han logrado terminar su casa. Ya que es toda de zinc y aun de tierra pero tiene la construcción a la mitad ya de concreto que esperan terminarla pronto para lograr tener mejor seguridad contra la delincuencia que asecha en el barrio. Su préstamo lo quiera para comprar ropa que no tiene en existencia, lo cual no le genera entradas, y de sus ganancias paga los gastos basicos, asi como zapatos, colas entre otros encargos que los clientes le hacen. Su anhelo es lograr mejorar su casa y terminarla toda de concreto y poder verla bonita.  Ya que por ser de pocos recursos no lo ha logrado.
texts.en:
Sra. Esperanza is 49 years old and lives in the neighborhood of Hialeah. She has been in the business of selling clothing, shoes, and slippers for several years in order to help her family because her husband’s wages are low. He works as a security guard and is paid poorly. It has been difficult for Doña Esperanza because her house is not yet finished. She already has the zinc and even the land, but the construction of the concrete portion is only halfway completed. Esperanza hopes to have the construction finished so that she can have greater security due to the crime that exists in the neighborhood.

This loan will be used to buy clothing that she does not have in stock. Her earnings will be used to pay for basic expenses and acquire other items, such as shoes and hair accessories that her customers request. Esperanza’s greatest wish is to improve her home by completing all the concrete work so that it looks beautiful. At the moment, she does not have enough resources to make this happen.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing, slippers, and shoes

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
God Is Able is a group of five borrowers, headed by Mary G.. She is 38 years old and did not go to school due to lack of financial support. She’s single, but has four children whose ages range from one-and-a-half years to 19 years old. All of her children attend school, with the exception of the youngest. she also to care for three siblings.

Mary sells fresh fish. She buys in bulk and sells at retail, and she has been doing this business for more than 12 years. She started her business with the help of her husband. She is challenged by delinquent customers and limited capital to get more fish for resale. Her business is located in the Waterside Market in downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

She indicated that her sales are booming due to her good manner of approach. Her hope is to improve her business, make big sales and build a house. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more fish to increase her sales.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mary G. is holding the sign. 

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia 's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

 

Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=10019

loans.use: To buy more fish to increase her sales

loans.name: Juntos Por El Progreso Group

texts.es:
Nuestros socios pertenecen al banco comunal “JUNTOS POR EL PROGRESO”; Nuestros socios viven en el distrito de Huanchac en la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

Nuestra socia es la  Sra. MARIEL.,  ella tiene 26 años de edad, es soltera la socia tiene 1 hijo la socia alterna sus diferentes actividades con el comercio minorista, Nuestra socia vende zapatillas desde hace 3 años atrás, en la calle trinitarias; Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en le adquisición de mercadería. 

Nuestros socios alternan sus diferentes actividades con el comercio minorista, dedicándose en su mayoría a vender ropa, restaurantes, venta de calzados, venta de artefactos, y una de ellas en el municipio de Cusco. Nuestros socios solicitan el préstamo para reinvertir en sus diferentes negocios.

Los  socios agradecen y valoran el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se comprometen a cumplir con el pago de sus deudas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our members belong to the community bank, Juntos por el Progreso (Together for Progress). Our members live in the district of Huanchac in Cusco Province, the Department of Cusco. Our members alternate their retail activities, focusing mainly on selling clothes, shoes, and artifacts in the city of Cusco. Our members seek loans to reinvest in their different businesses. The partners appreciate and value the support provided by this means and agree to comply with the payment of their debts on time. This partner, Ms. Marion, is 26 years old, single, and has one child. She alternates between several retail activities. She has been selling shoes for 3 years on Trinitarias Street. She is requesting a loan to buy merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Machelle Wilson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to invest in the acquisition of merchandise

loans.name: Nimia

texts.es:
La Sra. Nimia V., es casada y con hijos y vive en su casa, es una persona muy trabajadora y luchadora y se pueD. notar por la forma en como mantiene a su familia dentro D. las buenas costumbres y el trabajo. 
 Ella se dedica con sus hijos al negocio D. venta D. producto D. la canasta básica, artículos D. librería en general y ademas también preparan comestibles como empanadas, milanesas, panchos, contando con  una buena clientela formada en su barrio ya que a media cuadra D. su domicilio se encuentra un colegio, la cual le genera buen ingreso diario. 
 A la fecha la   titular ha retirado dicho préstamo para la compra  D. mercaderías para surtir mejor su tienda principalmente golosinas, enlatados, embutidos, carne, artículos D. limpieza.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nimia is married with children and has her own house. She is a hard working and goal oriented. One can see these characteristics in the way she cares for her family (they are well-mannered) and in her work. Nimia and her children sell basic products. They sell general office supplies and they also make prepared food such as “empanadas” (turnovers), “milanesas” (breaded and fried meat) and “panchos”. They have a large customer base in their neighborhood. A half block from their house there is a high school. This gives them many daily customers. At this time she would like a loan in order to buy merchandise in order to proviD. a greater variety of products for her store. She would buy candies, canned goods, sausage, meat and cleaning supplies.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy candy, sausage, canned goods and stationary items.

loans.name: Meme

texts.en:
Meme T. is from the village of Kinangay Sur, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old, is married, and has one infant child. Meme owns and operates a business providing motorcycle transport services. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Meme joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Meme is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to repair her existing vehicle to provide better service. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair her existing vehicle to provide better service

loans.name: Jeanine

texts.en:
Jeanine is 30 years old, married with 5 children.  Jeanine owns a small shop where she sells foodstuffs like rice, sugar, salt, cassava flour, etc.  Jeanine has been in this business for a long time and the hours of her business are from 7 am until 7 pm every day.

Jeanine is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing a variety of foodstuffs as they are highly demanded by a large number of her customers.  With this loan, as Jeanine purchases more foodstuffs for sale, she expects to earn more profit and this profit will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability and continue taking care of her family.

loans.use: purchasing a variety of goods which include foodstuffs

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es:
El señor Oscar T. se dedica al negocio de transporte de personas, tiene un taxi el cual esta ubicado en un punto en el Mall las Cascadas de la ciudad de Tegucigalpa,
se dedica a este tipo de actividad desde hace varios años y cuenta con dos unidades de transporte, el credito lo utilizara para la reparacion de una de las unidades y asi dejarla en buen estado para prestar un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mr. Oscar T. works in transportation. He has a taxi located at the point of the Mall las Cascadas in the city of Tegucigalpa, He has been doing this for several years and he has two transportation units. He will use the loan to repair one of the units to leave it in good condition to provide a better service for his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy automobile replacement parts

loans.name: Socorro

texts.es:
Doña Socorro de 60 años de edad vive en la comarca Los Brasiles jurisdiccion de comalapa junto a su familia compuesta por su esposo el Sr. Carlos Davila y sus 2 hijos de 40 y 35 años de edad, los que le ayudan al cuido de la finca. Desde hace 40 años se dedica a la actividad productiva.   

Esta solicitando su 1er credito con el objetivo de comprar terneros de desarrollo para engordarlos y posteriormente venderlos a un buen precio donde obtenga ganancias que le permitan  brindarle a su familia las condiciones necesarias del hogar.
texts.en:
Socorro, age 60, lives in the Los Brasiles region, which is in the Comalapa municipality. She lives with her family, which is comprised of her husband, Carlos Davila, and their two children. The children are 40 and 35 years old, and they help take care of the farm. She has been doing this work for 40 years. She is requesting her first loan to buy calves to fatten. Later, she will sell them for a good price. This will allow her to obtain the earnings that will provide her family with the necessary comforts at home.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy calves

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For Personal Expenses

loans.name: Florinda

texts.en:
Florinda F. is from the village of Cabisera 8. She is 51 years old. Florinda is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Florinda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Florinda has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells her raised animal.

In 2009, Florinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Florinda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Florinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 48-year-old married man and has 3 children. He is from Lebanon. He has been working as an experienced flooring worker for the past 30 years.  He works on floor covering, kitchen tiling, and bathroom tiling. Due to the long experience in this occupation, he has gained a good number of customers in addition of building a good business reputation. He is thankful for his business income, it provides a good life situation for his family and he was able to finalize the education of two of his children. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase new tools and supplies for a new project.
In the future, he is planning to open a construction office specialized in flooring and ceramics and he hopes he will reach this goal.

loans.use: to purchase new tools and supplies

loans.name: Thoa

texts.en: Thoa T. N. is 22 years old and has a small son.  She is a very hardworking farmer. She grows rice and corn in a paddy of 2,500 square meters. In addition,she  raises 100 hens. Thoa sells eggs and agricultural products to earn income to cover daily household expenses. She has participated in credit programs since 2008, and has effectively used and repaid her loans. Currently she is asking for a loan of 5,450,000,000 VND to buy fertilizer, pesticide and poultry feed.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and poultry feed.

loans.name: Marina Sonia

texts.en:
Marina Sonia Q. V. is twenty-five years old. She lives with her partner and her son in Asientomiento Humano in the district of Lambayeque. Her home is located in an area that is characterized by its high level of commercialization.

For the last three years Marina has operated a small grocery store out of her home, selling products to meet basic needs including bread, cheese, butter, drinks, soap and other items. She is well known in the area for her high level of service and the good quality of her products.

Marina is requesting this loan, her first with our institution, in order to purchase additional merchandise and expand her offerings to the public. The demand for her goods has been high in recent months and she wants to take advantage of this opportunity to grow her business. She hopes that she will also be able to increase her profits by purchasing a few items in bulk.

Marina is a very hardworking young woman who is constantly focused on bettering the life of her family. She would like to continue to expand her business and provide for the education of her son.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise, some in bulk

loans.name: Kibibi

texts.en:
Kibibi is a married woman.  She has four children, three of whom attend school; the other one is still too young for school. She owns a house that has access to electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For over seven years, Kibibi has operated a cloth-selling shop where she sells Kikois (an African version of a sarong) and shoes. She sells her goods to her neighbours and passersby. Seasonal weather is a challenge; during the hot summer months, demand for heavy clothes is lower. 

With the KES 20,000 loan she has requested, Kibibi wants to purchase a bale of Kikois and shoes for resale. She hopes to expand her business in the future.  She decided to join Yehu because of its minimal saving requirements.

loans.use: to purchase a bale of Kikois and shoes for resale

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana pertenece al banco comunal “La Granja”  de la comuna de La Cisterna. Su negocio es un almacén y bazar, en donde también tiene juegos de máquinas. Comenzó como sociedad hace más de un año, pero hace 2 meses se independizó. Antes de este negocio, Juana, vendía comida rápida.
